TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I draw your attention to the front page article by Mr Peter Hartcher in the Sydney Morning Herald of 25 April last in which there is reference to the continuing saga of the Dawkins affair and to an intervention purported to have been made by a Sydney firm of solicitors to require the members of the Opposition in this Parliament to desist from a course of inquiring of the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) about his involvement in the recommended change of Senior Trade Commissioner in Milan. The article itself is headed `Commission tried to stop attack on Dawkins: solicitor'. I table a copy of the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald of that date. The article goes on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: According to Mr Walton's solicitor, Mr Michael Kroger of the Melbourne firm Kroger and Kroger, he received an urgent phone call last Wednesday from a solicitor acting for the Trade Commission. At the same time, the Opposition was preparing a parliamentary attack on Mr Dawkins.
It continues:

The Commission's solicitor, from the firm Dawson Waldron, raised for the first time the possibility of a settlement of Mr Walton's case, but said it could not be discussed in an inflamed atmosphere, according to Mr Kroger.
Mr Kroger said: `He told me that as a precondition to a settlement, the current inflamed situation had to be brought to an end. A calm atmosphere was needed.
`He asked me to immediately send a telex to the Opposition saying that Walton's position was not helped by a parliamentary uproar, and urging the Opposition to abandon its attack on Dawkins.'

The article continues to identify the extent to which the solicitors for the Trade Commission attempted to place pressure upon the Opposition in this place so that we would not proceed with our line of questioning to the Minister for Trade which, of course, resulted in his grave embarrassment on the last occasion that the matter was before the House. We await later answers in this House on the same matter today.

Madam Speaker, I draw your attention to May's Parliamentary Practice which identifies one of the causes of a breach of parliamentary privilege as attempts by improper means to influence members in their parliamentary conduct. While in this instance there is certainly no direct suggestion of fee or reward to any member, certainly page 157 of Parliamentary Practice, in an extension of this reference, in talking about attempted intimidation of members, refers to `sending a letter to Members threatening them to vote for a particular bill would be regarded as a treasonable act by a future administration' as being a case of breach of privilege.

At page 158, we see further that acts tending indirectly to obstruct members in the discharge of their duty are regarded as a breach of privilege. If we turn from May to Pettifer's House of Representatives Practice, we find on page 655 reference to `Attempts by improper means to influence Members in their parliamentary conduct'. It also refers to attempted intimidation of members and makes reference to the fact that any suggestion that might impair the complete freedom of members within the Parliament should be regarded as a breach of parliamentary privilege.

Madam Speaker, I do not want to delay the House but I point out that this is endorsed not only in Pettifer's House of Representatives Practice but also in Odgers's Australian Senate Practice, and I turn your attention to page 646, which refers to the degree to which there can be a breach of parliamentary privilege where a threat by people outside the Parliament to take or not take certain action is used as an attempt to change the action of members of the Parliament. As I have said, the reference is on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald of 25 April and it shows a direct attempt by solicitors, on behalf of the Trade Commission, to influence the members of the Opposition in this place in terms of questioning they might pursue with the objective of apparently arranging for a settlement of the Tom Walton affair with either solicitors representing the Minister for Trade or solicitors representing the Trade Commission. Madam Speaker, I put it to you that there is a prima facie case and suggest that you consider the issues at your earliest opportunity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I wish to speak on the same matter. It has been suggested by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) that you should consider a matter of privilege. So that you have a full and, might I say, accurate picture I would like to refer to this matter myself. I, of course, was very alarmed on seeing that story and made inquiries of the Trade Commission in terms of its alleged involvement in this incident. I have not a newspaper article, but a signed statement from Dawson Waldron, the solicitors who acted for the Commission in this regard, and I will read it to the House. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: We refer to the report in the Sydney Morning Herald of Friday, 25 April, 1986 dealing with Mr Walton.
The background to our conversation with Mr Walton's solicitor and the substance of the conversation are as follows:

1. The Acting Managing Director of the Commission advised us on 16 April, 1986 that a member of the Commission's staff had approached him claiming that he had been in recent contact with Mr Walton and his solicitor, Mr Michael Kroger. The staff member had advised the Acting Managing Director that Mr Walton and Mr Kroger were concerned about the publicity being attracted by the matter which they judged to be embarrassing to Mr Walton. Mr Kroger had indicated a desire to open up communications with a view to removing the matter from public gaze.

2. The Acting Managing Director asked that we contact Mr Kroger to suggest that he might consider sending a telex as a matter of urgency to the Opposition spokesman for Trade, Mr Braithwaite, stating that the current publicity being given to the case in the Parliament was embarrassing his client and was prejudicing discussions regarding Mr Walton's employment.
3. We telephoned Mr Kroger on Wednesday, 16 April, 1986 leaving a message for him to return our call. He returned our call at approximately 2.15 p.m. that day.

4. In accordance with our instructions, we suggested to Mr Kroger that he consider sending a telex to Mr Braithwaite stating that the current publicity being given to the case in the Parliament was embarrassing his client and was prejudicing discussions regarding Mr Walton's employment.

5. Mr Kroger indicated that he was prepared to send such a telex but only if a settlement or resolution could be reached between the Commission and Mr Walton regarding his future. In response to a direct question from ourselves, Mr Kroger confirmed that such a settlement or resolution was a condition precedent to him de-publicising the case. He went on to add that if some mutually agree- able arrangement could be reached, his client would undertake not to approach members of the Opposition or members of the press and that threatened legal proceedings against the Minister for Trade would not go ahead.
6. We said we had no instructions to put any such proposition or terms of settlement to Mr Walton.

7. Mr Kroger reiterated that he was not willing to send a telex to the Opposition along the lines suggested in the absence of some resolution or settlement of Mr Walton's future. We said we would convey his remarks to the Commission and obtain further instructions on whether the Commission was prepared to make any such proposal. We indicated that we thought this unlikely.

In the light of this background there are three principal errors in the account of the conver- sation contained in the Sydney Morning Herald report. They are: Firstly, the conversation took place on 16 April 1986 and not 23 April 1986; Secondly, the telephone call resulted from an initiative by Mr Walton and his solicitor and not the Commission or ourselves; Thirdly, we did not raise the possibility of a settlement and we did not suggest that as a precondition to a settlement the current inflamed situation had to be brought to an end. On the contrary, it was Mr Kroger who raised the possibility of a settlement and who indicated that a settlement was a condition precedent to his depublicising the case. We specifically disclaimed any instructions to propose a resolution or settlement of Mr Walton's future and indicated that we thought it unlikely that the Commission would supply such instructions. There has been no other conversation or contact between us and Mr Kroger in relation to this matter.

So, far from this being a matter which the Commission raised, it was raised by Mr Kroger or Mr Walton. In relation to depublicising the matter, I was prepared to co-operate and said that I would raise the matter only if it were raised in Parliament. So, Madam Speaker, when you are considering this matter of privilege, you might like to have with you the document from which I have read and which I now table.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: UNITED STATES WHEAT SALE: YEMEN ARAB REPUBLIC

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Primary Industry: Does the recent American subsidised wheat sale to the Yemen Arab Republic represent a breach of the assurances provided to the Prime Minister by the United States Administration during his recent visit to Washington?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the concern of the honourable member. The Yemen Arab Republic is an important Australian market. We supplied 100 per cent of its wheat requirements in 1984-85. Australia still expects to sell around 400,000 tonnes of wheat to the Yemen Arab Republic this year. This is the quantity we have been selling there in recent years. However, I would like to inform the House that there have been some changes in the circumstances of the market. Until this year, besides Australia's wheat sales, the Yemen Arab Republic was also taking 132,000 tonnes of flour from the European Economic Community. Yemen has now opened a new flour mill with the consequence that there is now an expanded wheat market in the Yemen Arab Republic. Some estimate that to be up to 600,000 tonnes a year. The United States subsidised wheat sale just announced will be replacing European Community flour. Australia will still be able to make its normal wheat sales into the market.

ANSWER.PARA: Nonetheless, there are some causes for concern. The Yemen Arab Republic is a market where subsidies have not previously been used. This sale by the United States is clearly breaking new ground. Although it can be said that the United States wheat sale is replacing EEC flour and that an EEC bid for the contract had been lodged, the quality of wheat available from the Community would not have been suitable. This suggests that Australia may have won this contract in the absence of the United States export enhancement program subsidy. For these reasons we shall be using the avenues established by the Prime Minister during his trip to Washington to review the issues involved with the United States Administration. Our aim will be to minimise further subsidised competition. I repeat: In the circumstances now prevailing in the Yemen Arab Republic market we can expect Australia to maintain its 400,000 tonnes contracted level of sales.

—With my approval or permission-
—With your knowledge?

—Will the Minister for Defence inform the House of measures that he is taking to create a more efficient relationship between the Department of Defence and Australian industry in the provision of equipment used to carry out defence projects?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. I am pleased to say that I have approved a major program of review, which has been released to Australian industry-of Commonwealth-owned machinery and plant and other production equipment and facilities. The equipment which comprises nearly 20,000 items is currently issued on loan or lease to hundreds of Australian companies which are current or previous contractors to my Department or is held in store. I think it is high time that this enormous quantity of Commonwealth assets was looked at so that industry can make better use of it for commercial and defence work. Some items are being used intensively now but others have been held for 30 years with very little use. Facilities have accumulated over the years as needed for new defence projects and all items currently on loan to industry will be reviewed as quickly as possible. Those that are not required to meet current contracts will be either offered to companies currently using them or disposed of at auction. The Commonwealth might also wish to retain ownership of a very small number of items against future strategic requirements, but it is our intention in relation to future projects to keep Commonwealth ownership of assets to an absolute minimum. That does not mean a reduction in the Government's commitment to self-reliance and Australian industry support of defence. It reflects our intention to do business with industry on a normal commercial basis and to minimise government impediments to future commercial exploitation of the skills and capabilities gained through defence work.

ANSWER.PARA: The items currently available for review, such as the floating crane and plant for making clockwork mechanisms for fuses, are expected to realise at least $14m when sold. Other items in use by industry in fulfilling current contracts will be reviewed as those contracts expire. The total book value of all items is approximately $90m, $39m of which relates to the FA18 project. In addition to the revenue gained from the sale, there will be some savings in the administrative area, as currently each item carries a Commonwealth plant number and has to be checked annually. Such items include things like urns for tea making and the other odd thing here and there. Keeping those items on the books is a hell of a waste. In some cases, though, rent is being charged where the equipment is being used for non-defence purposes, so there will be a slight reduction in revenue there. All in all, as I have said, we expect immediately $14m worth of savings, effectively, from the proceeds of the sale and ultimately savings could be up to $90m.

—Has the attention of the Special Minister of State been drawn to the report on this morning's Australian Broadcasting Corporation news of the horrendous death toll on Australian Capital Territory roads due to the lack of policing? Is there any truth in the report that the transfer of 42 police from Canberra to the national crime investigation is pending?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I was concerned to be told about the report on the radio this morning of the horrendous death toll on Australian Capital Territory roads. Whilst it may not concern a great number of members in this Parliament, it certainly is of concern to the community here in Canberra. The first thing to say about the Australian Capital Territory policing is that there has been a significant increase in the resources available to the Australian Federal Police since its formation. As I have said in the Parliament previously, the disposition of these resources is a matter for the Commissioner; but I understand that there has been an increase in the resources allocated to road traffic policing and rescue. There is no evidence of any significant increase in the road toll in the Australian Capital Territory over earlier years. There have been 13 fatalities in the Territory so far in 1986, which compares with nine in 1985 and thirteen in 1984, over the same period.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no truth in the report that 42 police officers from Canberra have been transferred to the national crime investigation. There are discussions within the Government about guarding duties being transferred to my colleague who is in charge of protective services. This would have no effect whatsoever on Australian Capital Territory road policing. While it is true to say that Canberra policing is not given a higher priority in the recent statement of objectives and priorities, this is not a downgrading of Canberra but an upgrading of the national issues of organised crime and drug trafficking. I hope that the community of Canberra can better understand the situation of the Australian Federal Police as a result of this information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Trade. I refer to the Minister's answer to a question on notice, tabled on 15 April, in which, referring to two candidates under final consideration for Thomas Walton's position, that of Senior Trade Commissioner in Milan, the Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: A decision has not yet been taken, on which applicant will be appointed.

I now ask the Minister whether at that time he was aware that, first, Sir Peter Abeles had recommended Mr Klein for Mr Walton's position; secondly, that a selection committee from the Trade Commission had recommended Mr Klein's appointment to that position; thirdly, until Opposition pressure mounted against his appointment, Mr Klein was to go on secondment for training to take up Mr Walton's position; and, fourthly, a replacement for Mr Klein, in the office of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, had already been decided upon?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Dawson raises a number of questions which I will deal with in some detail. In the first instance, in my replies about this matter, I have made it perfectly clear that at no stage have I had any dealings with the selection process which the Commission decided to institute in relation to the appointment of someone to fill the forthcoming vacancy in Milan. Of course, the Opposition is attempting to fabricate a case-that I initiated the recall of Mr Walton for one reason and for one reason only, that is, to secure the appointment of someone whom it chooses to call a crony.

ANSWER.PARA: It has never been my intention to publicly canvass the reasons behind Mr Walton's recall, or indeed his shortcomings. All the more reason, of course, because once I ordered his recall on 2 December he in fact complied with that request and indicated that he would be leaving the post on 5 February. However, since the middle of January-after I ceased to have any dealings in the matter of his recall or indeed in the choice of a replacement-this matter has become a bizarre and politically inspired campaign full of half truths and mistruths.

I want to say, Madam Speaker, that, in order that there should be a very clear understanding of all the facts which have led up to my decision, I take this opportunity of tabling a report prepared by the Acting Secretary of my Department, which gives the details in relation to this matter. It will be seen that the decision to recall Mr Walton-a decision taken by me-was taken in such a way that I at all times acted properly, as will be indicated from a reading of the report prepared by Mr Lightowler. Secondly, it is suggested that I tried to interfere with the selection process, and that is what is being suggested here again by the honourable member for Dawson. I repeat that at no time did I try to influence the selection process. That is a matter which was confirmed before the Senate Estimates Committee by the Acting Deputy Managing Director of the Commission, and more recently by the Managing Director of the Trade Commission. I take the opportunity to table those documents as well.

The case which is attempted to be made against me relies very much on the word of Mr Walton and, I might say, the fertile imagination of his Melbourne solicitor. Let us take Mr Walton's remarks in relation to this matter one by one. Let me say that the first and most glaring instance of Mr Walton's unreliability is the fact that he suggests that, in relation to certain minutes which have now become very famous, I had said that they contained political dynamite. No one who has read those minutes can suggest where that political dynamite might be. He then said he was never advised of the Department or anyone else having any reservations about his capacity. It will be seen from the Lightowler report that that point is entirely disproved and that Mr Walton was being less than frank in making that comment.

In two separate statements made less than a week apart last year, on the one hand he said that I engaged in a discussion with him, I swore at him, I gave him heated instructions and, on the other, within a week he was saying that while I was with him in Rome we exchanged nothing more than formal salutations. That, again, will be seen from a reading of the Lightowler report. So this is the word that is being relied upon by those who doubt my account of the events which have led to this decision. Last week Mr Walton said that he had not been involved in any impropriety and he had received no reprimand. This matter, of course, was repeated today and yesterday in newspapers. So that that matter is firmly on the record, I table the reprimand, which indicates quite clearly that it was seen by Mr Walton.

Next, of course, we have the questions from the Opposition in regard to how I had misused the term `retirement post' in relation to Mr Walton's description of his posting to Milan. Again, let me indicate that this expression was used by Mr Walton. I table a document dated 27 August 1985 which indicates inter alia the reasons why his appointment should be continued. I might say that all of the reasons he advanced are personal. None of them is related to advancing any of Australia's trading interests. Of course, because it was raised during the Senate committee hearing last week and because some Opposition senators disputed my claim, the officers made a further search of the file which showed that as early as 1981 Mr Walton was first indicating his desire for a retirement post of the kind described. I table that document as well.

I suppose that the worst of the misrepresentations which have been involved in this matter are those which were the subject of the intervention of the Leader of the National Party of Australia at the beginning of today's parliamentary sitting. There was the suggestion that I or someone acting on my behalf had somehow attempted to influence this matter or the way in which it would be dealt with in this Parliament. That is obviously untrue and indicates once more why those acting either on Mr Walton's behalf or on their own behalf have been responsible for some of the most outrageous misrepresentations as far as this matter is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Madam Speaker. I asked four questions and got no answers to any of them.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member is aware of that.

—I direct my question to the Attorney-General. I refer to the proposed meat processing consortium involving at least four of Australia's largest meat companies. As this merger could mean the loss of up to 2,000 jobs in Queensland and New South Wales meat works, could lock the majority of graziers into a one price only arrangement for their cattle, could bring about the demise of many of the 31 licensed meat works in Queensland and could create a virtual monopoly in the meat processing industry, will he have the proposed consortium immediately investigated under the anti-cartel buying provisions and the anti-monopoly provisions of the Trade Practices Act?

So we there see, pursuant to the principles of the Trade Practices Act, the safeguards that are there not only for producers but also consumers. It would appear at this stage that the matter is worthy of examination. I understand that representations have been made by the honourable member to members of my Department. TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the Prescribed Goods (General) Orders, as amended, the Export Control Orders No. 7 of 1986 and accompanying explanatory statement. Amendments to the Prescribed Goods (General) Orders made under the Export Control Act 1982 entered into force on 18 February 1986, and were not disallowed by this House within the statutory time limit. They have, however, run into trouble in the Senate, with the threat of a disallowance vote to be taken there on 30 April 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will be well aware that these Orders were introduced as a result of a recent Federal Court full bench decision which found that the law did not give effect to the Government's intentions in regard to one aspect of the provision of a cost effective export inspection service by the Department of Primary Industry.

The amendments gave my Department the legal right to take into account issues affecting management efficiency, staff safety, and welfare of relevant export industries when considering requests to provide services; and also gave the Minister for Primary Industry the right to intervene in departmental decision-making processes where it is in the national interest to do so. They also provide for decisions by officials to be reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. If the amendments were not made, the Orders would have required my Department to provide inspection services unless `impossible' to do so, regardless of the consequences to Australia, the cost, or any consideration of staff welfare and safety. I would have had no clearly defined right to become involved, even though I am answerable to this Parliament for the actions of my Department. The provisions break no new ground in either administrative law or delegated legislation. Similar provisions are contained in many pieces of legislation passed by this Parliament and previous parliaments.

The amendments were considered by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and specialised legal advice was received by that committee. As honourable members will be aware, the Committee is a bipartisan Committee comprising members of the major political parties which examines all delegated legislation to ascertain whether the legislation satisfies the following four principles: First, that it is in accordance with the statute; secondly, that it does not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties; thirdly, that it does not unduly make the rights and liberties of the citizens dependent upon administrative decisions which are not subject to review of their merits by a judicial or other independent tribunal, and, fourthly, that it does not contain matter more appropriate for parliamentary enactment. The Chairman of the Committee told the Senate on 19 March 1986 that after considering the Orders generally and the legal adviser's report in particular, the Committee concluded that it could not object to the Orders under its principles and that the Committee did not consider that any of its principles were infringed.

In this particular issue there has been too much concentration on the political aspects of the Mudginberri abattoir dispute and the subsequent legal proceedings and not enough on the problems that the amendments to the legislation are designed to overcome. The amendments were not made to allow the Government to avoid its responsibilities or to give the unions more power. They are in the interest of proper government administration and are to correct what is widely acknowledged to be a deficiency in existing legislation. However, for political reasons the Opposition parties chose to oppose the changes in this House and the Senate. I say `for political reasons' because, while their record of public administration leaves much to be desired, I cannot believe that their grasp of the principles of proper administration is so poor as for them to oppose the changes on any other grounds.

This House passed the changes, but the Opposition parties in the Senate threatened to disallow the Orders. As a consequence, the Senate was asked for time to refer the matter to the industry for further consideration, as I believed that the meat industry, in particular, needed more time to consider the issues. I was given until 30 April. Because of the importance to the meat industry I arranged for the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council-AMLIPC-to look at the issue. The Chairman of the Inspection Policy Council has also provided me with a view. Indications from the first meeting of the AMLIPC held to discuss the issue were that it felt the Orders as proposed were too broad. As a result senior officials from my Department discussed the matter with the AMLIPC and put before the Council for consideration revised wording of the Orders to make the conditions of the discretion more specific. I believe that the reworded Orders adequately address industry's concerns and consequently the Government is willing to compromise and make changes to the Orders put before the Senate in an effort to find common ground.

In framing these amendments, the Government has considered the need of Australia's meat and livestock industry to develop and maintain a reputation as a reliable supplier on the international market. However, AMLIPC was only able to agree unanimously that provision should be made for withholding inspection services where staff are not available to satisfy all applications within applicable budgetary limits and where there is an occupational health or safety risk.

The majority of AMLIPC members were not supportive of the other provisions, namely, that inspection services might be temporarily withheld where there is a risk of physical assault or intimidation of staff, even where the police are agreed that there is a risk, or where there is a need for a cooling-off period in the event of an industrial dispute-although they did offer to have the industry further consider the industrial relations aspects at a later date. The AMLIPC also opposed any provision which would give the Minister a right to intervene in departmental decision making when the national interest is involved. The previous views expressed by the opposition parties in this House and in the Senate on ministerial involvement are difficult to fathom. National interest in this context covers, I believe, the interests of the industry and the public interest, and it is clear that there may be times when the public interest is greater than that of the industry and this must at least be able to be taken into account without recourse to the courts.

The unclear position of the responsible Minister's involvement in officials' decisions where national interest considerations may be involved runs contrary to all the principles of our system of elected government. The attitude by some industry groups and by the Opposition to the realities of managing a complex service industry seems blinkered to me, possibly because the issue is still being clouded by the emotionalism attached to Mudginberri and by political considerations of the organisations concerned. Quite frankly, it is beyond me how anyone can refuse to agree to clarify the law where staff safety is involved or where some cooling-off period for industrial negotiation is desirable. On the question of staff safety, the inspection service has on a number of occasions been confronted with staff being placed at physical risk by threats of violence or actual violence. In a very recent incident such threats led to an inspector being physically assaulted and injured off the premises. The service must not be put in a position where there are any doubts about its legal right to clear its staff from such situations.

Further, it should be recognised that most industrial disputes involving inspection staff are localised and short in duration being resolved by level-headed conciliatory negotiation. To inflame such minor disputes by immediately trying to force inspectors to work regardless of the circumstances and merits of the case is stupid in industrial relations terms. We must allow management the flexibility to have a short cooling-off period to negotiate and attempt a conciliation. My view is that we have a recipe for industrial disaster if the Orders are not amended. Those opposed to the amendments are, in fact, putting more power in the hands of the unions, for the unions are now the only group that has any discretion. Recognising the importance of these issues, the Inspection Policy Council while not being unaminous on the matter is in general agreement with the inclusion of provisions that would allow services to be withheld where availability and management efficiency are involved and in the interests of staff safety and to provide an industrial relations cooling-off period. The proposal to allow ministerial intervention is also generally supported by the IPC on the grounds that it will effectively provide an additional avenue for appeal.

I would point out that the IPC has indicated to me previously its unaminous view that it is untenable to have the inspection service and the Government placed in the position where they have little say in the provision of an inspection service, yet are held fully accountable for that service. Following receipt of this advice from AMLIPC and IPC, I have had new Orders prepared. The new Orders, which were gazetted and tabled in this House and in the Senate today, are explained in the explanatory statement. Briefly, they repeal the existing provisions and substitute more detailed criteria under which a discretion may be exercised. The criteria are drafted so as to leave some scope for negotiations to take place in an industrial dispute and to give flexibility where there is physical threat to staff. In the ministerial directions provision, the Minister would be required to consult directly with relevant industry bodies before making any direction on national interest grounds. The House should note that industry supports Orders 100A and 100B. While the new Orders 100A and 100B go some way to resolving the administrative problems, industrial, staff safety and public accountability aspects are not, however, recognised. What the industry is doing is asking the management of the inspection service to run its operation in a commercial way without the discretion that industry demands in its daily businesses.

I notice from the Hansard of the Senate debate of 19 March 1986 that there was some concern expressed that ministerial direction should be provided for in the principal Act, rather than orders. I gather this was despite the view of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. If the placement of new orders 111a.1 and 111a.2 remains the only concern I would be agreeable to amending the Export Control Act 1982 accordingly and repealing the relevant orders at that time.

I hope that common sense now prevails in the Senate. The orders as now presented represent a genuine attempt by this Government to meet the requests of industry. They reflect my concern that disallowance would result, over time, in greater costs and detract from the ongoing drive to provide inspection services in an efficient and cost effective way in accordance with the accepted principles of good public administration. The judgment of the Full Bench is very clear on the point that under the previous law the Inspection Service must provide services unless it is actually impossible to do so. The full bench clearly indicated that the policy aspects could be fixed by amending the orders, and the Government has taken this course of action. If any of the new orders are disallowed, I wish to make it clear that the Inspection Service will abide by the law, in a sensible, non-emotional way. But it will not, as some people seem to think, disregard the law when it suits the industry for it to do so. I present the following paper:

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`Orders 100c, 100d and 111a of the Prescribed Goods (General) Orders, as contained in Prescribed Goods (General) Orders as amended (Amendment), being Export Control Orders No. 7 of 1986, made under the Export Control Act 1982, be disallowed'.

The debate on these export control orders arises from the failure of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) to execute his ministerial duty in providing Commonwealth meat inspectors during the picketing at the Mudginberri abattoir. This whole issue has been a watershed for excessive union power in Australia. It has also exposed the extent to which this Government is prepared to lock itself into actions, no matter how irresponsible they may be, to preserve excessive union power. I have sought the disallowance of control of the former orders, on behalf of not only the meat export industries which were directly affected by these changes to export inspection laws but also all Australians, employees and employers alike, who value their rights and freedoms in our society.

The previous orders flowed directly from an incident at the remote abattoir at Mudginberri in the Northern Territory. At the heart of the incident was the right of individual employees to negotiate their own conditions of employment and reach agreements on employment conditions, including wage rates, without the demands and approval of their union. That is the heart of this issue, let there be no mistake. It was an attempt to stop voluntary agreements between employees and employers. The orders 100a and 111a, if passed, would have effectively given the green light to ongoing industrial disruption and trade union standover tactics in the meat export industry, aimed at preventing voluntary agreements serving the best interests of employees and employers and achieving productivity gains.

Before responding to the Minister's new orders, I must emphasise why this matter has become a watershed for Labor and excessive union power. The orders would have inserted a vaguely-defined ministerial discretion into export inspection laws. The Hawke Labor Government cannot deny that it was seeking a cop-out clause in the event of a repeat of the Mudginberri experience. Honourable members will recall that the Full Bench of the Federal Court of Australia, on 19 December last, ruled that the Minister had an obligation, not a discretion, to provide export inspection services to the abattoir.

I want to put this issue into its historical perspective. Last year employees at the Mudginberri abattoir met with management to discuss their terms of employment, including pay rates. They agreed to introduce a new set of terms which increased productivity and on average doubled the pay rates of the workers. This agreement was approved by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, but the union could not resist trying to get its sticky fingers into the act. The agreement was reached without the big union bosses' involvement or approval. They feared that it would create a precedent, exploding the myth that unions are necessary to protect the workers. The union bosses rightly feared that the employees themselves could do far better by negotiating with their bosses than by adhering to an inflexible, unacceptable award that the union has previously achieved. So the union decided on action to be taken to sabotage the deal, if possible.

It is also curiously coincidental that export meat inspectors employed by the Commonwealth were moved off the Mudginberri premises and back to the township of Jabiru. Shortly after this incident, a picket line was established by the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, a few kilometres away from the works. Was this not splendid timing? One could be forgiven for believing that there was collusion.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no collusion, you know that. I have explained that to you. You know full well there was no collusion.
—Some people have said that it was collusion.
—Well, that is not true.

—I will take the Minister's word for it. He says that it was not collusion, but it appeared to be. It seemed to be very coincidental. Of course, the abattoir workers wanted to continue the killing and boning operations uninterrupted, but the presence of a picket line established by the union, which claimed to represent them, effectively forced the cessation of export trade from the abattoir. The proprietor, Mr Pendarvis, did not buckle under the immense pressure of the AMIEU and, behind it, the faceless operational commanders at the Australian Council of Trade Unions headquarters. He stuck to his guns and for that he must get full credit. He believed that his workers had the right to make their own agreement. The courts have vindicated those actions. The outrageous treatment of Mr Pendarvis, which resulted from the Hawke Government's failure to ensure that export inspections were carried out, has been exposed by the Full Bench of the Federal Court of Australia, which on 19 December ruled that the Minister had an obligation, not a discretion, to provide that export inspection service. The response of the Government was to lodge an appeal to the High Court of Australia. That appeal was thrown out on 21 February this year. Clearly, the Government did not have a leg to stand on. On 4 February the Minister announced that he had discussed with the Australian Meat and Live-stock Inspection Policy Council his intention to insert ministerial discretion into the export laws. It was not so much a discussion; the announcement was presented to the Policy Council as a fait accompli.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note the reaction of the Meat and Live-stock Industry Policy Council now that it has been given time by the Opposition to consider that matter. The Council has taken a very different position from that of the Minister. I will raise those differences shortly because, once again, they reveal the real intentions of this Government. Any impartial observer will recognise that the web of ACTU control over the industrial relations system is the driving force behind the Government's actions. These orders are a rerun of those that ran into trouble in the Senate, with a threat of disallowance this coming Wednesday. In spite of consultations with the Industry Policy Council, which accepts two of the four conditions in the proposed orders, the Minister has come back using complicated provisions, with one intent-that is, to give him the discretion that he originally attempted to snake through the Parliament last month.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—The Minister says `rubbish'. But he is back here with exactly the same purpose. He is trying to get a discretion for himself. He does not want to be in a situation of having to provide export inspection services in the event of another picket line being set up by the union. Who is he protecting? He is protecting those union bosses; that is who he is trying to protect.
—Shameful!

—It is absolutely shameful action. In this context I note that the Minister has claimed that the Inspection Policy Council has indicated its view that ministerial intervention is untenable. Supporting the Government view were the consumer representatives and, surprisingly, two Government representatives and the ministerial-appointed Chairman! They were the only ones who supported the Government. The only ones who supported it were the consumer representatives, the two Government representatives and the Government-appointed Chairman. Of course, they had to support the Minister. But all of the meat and livestock industry representatives were totally in agreement with the advice of the IPC.

SPEECH.PARA: In adding a further two orders, the Minister has introduced two plausible orders requiring him to consult with some members of the affected industries. But the affected industries will not have a bar of it. The Opposition has no objection to the intent of orders 100a and 100b, with one qualification; in order 100a the Minister has sought to give the Secretary to the Department a discretion by the use of the verb `may'. We are not satisfied with this verb. We believe the order should state `shall'. Unless the Minister is prepared to substitute `may' for `shall' we will take appropriate action in the Senate. I am sorry that the Minister has left the chamber in disgust. I do not know where he has gone but he has gone away. I hope that somebody makes a note of that because it is very important.

Turning to the specific orders to which the Opposition objects, I raise, firstly, order 100C. This refers to the departmental Secretary making some judgment about the potential for violence if there is a picket. Such a discretion to the Department, or effectively to the Minister, is not justifiable. I share the view of the Industry Policy Council and the National Farmers Federation that this is first and foremost a matter for civil law. Orders such as these are not an appropriate place for such a discretion. What an incredible business it is to have this sort of provision whereby the Minister tries to give himself a discretion in case there is a threat of intimidation or violence. Indeed, the Federal Court decision on 19 December left open the scope for a service not to be provided under circumstances where such provision was a physical impossibility.

I also make the point that police powers can be invoked in situations such as Mudginberri, dependent only on the political will power of the State or Territory. There is a grave danger that the inclusion of 100C would be interpreted, certainly at a legal level, as an invitation to use the potential for violence as an excuse not to provide meat inspectors. Let us be clear that meat inspections are a government monopoly service for which the meat producers pay at least 50 per cent. There is no alternative service if government inspectors are not available. Therefore, it is necessary to ensure that there are safeguards against the misuse of such monopoly power; Mudginberri was the prime example. I ask the Government, the Minister or whoever is in charge of the House at the moment-there are only two Government members here-whether the Government would invoke a similar clause in legislation which dealt with picket lines established by the Builders Labourers Federation. There is silence. Government members would prefer not to answer that question. I can understand why they would not want to answer that question, but it is an interesting question to ponder.

The Opposition is not setting out to expose people to violence in seeking to disallow order 100C. We simply make the point that this power is not needed because civil law provides for civil protection of people. We will not open the way for virtual blackmail to be enforced upon the Minister or the Secretary to the Department. Clearly, order 100D would give the power of temporary determination pending what could be a long drawn out court or industry consultation proceeding. By approving 100C, this Parliament would be setting an outrageous precedent. The precedent goes well beyond the inspection service. It goes to the heart of the Government's responsibility as an employer of labour providing community services. If this precedent is enforced it means that, where a Minister makes a judgment that an industrial dispute is likely to risk government employees or their families, the Government should have the discretion not to provide those services. Take the example of a picket line being in place and Customs or quarantine officers being involved. The Government may well say: `It is better to stay out than to take on the unions'. To take the argument further, what would happen if the Commissioner of Police made a judgment that the safety of police officers and their families was at risk if they crossed a picket or took action to protect civil order. This would give the union movement an effective power of veto over government services to the community.

The parallel should be noted. The export inspection service polices health and hygiene standards and is essential by law for the export of produce. Order 111a is more offensive still. This is a re-write of the national interest provision which would offer a carte blanche discretionary power. Honourable members should note the words. The Minister, after carefully trying to look impartial in other sections, comes out with these words:
Notwithstanding anything provided in Orders, where the Minister considers it is desirable, taking into account the national interest . . .

And so the statement goes on, requiring only that the Minister consult with what are defined as `relevant industry bodies'. Look at what he had done with the advice of the Industry Policy Council on Orders 100c, 100d and 111a. He has ignored them. Could an industry trust a union-dominated government in these circumstances? Of course it could not.

TALK.START.PARA: —No way. We know what happened at Mudginberri.

—Exactly. Further, let me stress that, under the wording of these changes, the relevant industry organisations need not include any of the constituent councils of the National Farmers Federation which represent the payers of half the export inspection costs. I wish to indicate that the farm bodies are opposed to these orders. On 23 April the President of the National Farmers Federation, Mr McLachlan, advised me that the Federation supported the Industry Council in its fight against the broad powers of discretion sought by the Minister. I fully share Mr McLachlan's concern. The Opposition is not prepared to stand by and watch this nation being sold out to the domination of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, nor are the vast majority of Australian citizens. We will fight these changes tooth and nail and, therefore, I move for the disallowance of these orders.
-Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. There can be no doubt why this matter is before the House at the moment. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has come into this chamber to make changes to the Export Control Act, firstly, because of his failure to act in accordance with his responsibilities as set out under that Act and is abrogating his responsibilities in favour of union domination. Secondly, this matter is back in this chamber because the Senate would not approve the original changes and requested the Minister to have further negotiations with the industry. While some of those consultations have taken place, I just question whether the Minister has had consultations and reached agreement with the major organisation representing beef producers in Australia; that is, the National Farmers Federation. If consultations were held, they were less than effective.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, this matter is before the House because of the Mudginberri dispute, with which the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) is very familiar. If it had not been for the Mudginberri dispute, this matter would not have crystallised. The Mudginberri decision was a watershed decision in that management was able to reach an agreement with the work force on providing the necessary productivity at a cost that was both fair and reasonable to the employer and the employees. It was because the management did not get the approval of the unions and the meat inspectors that this dispute came about. At the height of that dispute I was a member of a group of parliamentarians who went into the area and there saw the union picket which had been set up in the area without a permit. There were certain calls on the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) to do something about it but he refused to do anything because he was frightened of confronting the unions in such an impossible situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —A monumental failure of duty by the Minister.

—I must agree with that. I might add that there was a failure by two Ministers, not just one. I repeat that it was the lack of responsibility on the part of both Ministers that brought this situation to a head. The Minister for Primary Industry has said that this sort of thing will come about only in impossible situations. That picket involved four members of the union. They did not pose any threat to anybody legally entering the area, and that is what we were doing. I believe that the suggestion that some risk to safety was involved for any Commonwealth meat inspectors who passed the picket line is absolute nonsense. The Minister abrogated his responsibility in favour of being told what the union interest was and doing what it said.

SPEECH.PARA: When we come to the national interest we must ask: What does the Government consider to be the national interest in this case? Is it just that the Government is prepared to knuckle under to union interest? I suggest to members of this Parliament that in this case the national interest was one which we have to address as a nation; that is, our ability to earn export dollars and to try to bridge the trade deficit gap of about $1 billion each month. Mudginberri, in its own small way, was doing that. As I understand it, a market of about $4m per year in the European Community and elsewhere is actually being lost or is certainly under threat at the moment. Four million dollars may not sound much to a union but it means a lot to a private company which is trying to earn, trying to be productive and trying to do its part for Australia in this regard. I think we should confirm at this time that national interest is not union interest. It is not the ACTU's interest; it is the interest of those producers and those people who are trying to help the Australian economy. Pendarvis's crime was that he tried to buck the union system.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the workers.

—And the workers. In this case the workers were not represented within his meatworks because he was prepared to enter into an agreement. Again that could be a benchmark as far as future agreements with the beef industry in Australia are concerned. Neither the beef industry nor Australia would have been an insignificant beneficiary of any arrangement that might have been made there. In 1984-85, chilled or frozen beef and veal contributed $1,750m to our exports and our balance of payments.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not fool ourselves. The Minister abrogated his responsibilities to the national interest by not trying to get exports up and production up simply to obey the dictates of the union. It is interesting to note that the decision that was made in this regard by the Full Bench of the Federal Court of Australia indicated that the Minister had an obligation-not a discretion-to act. He is now trying to run away from that obligation he has to Australian primary industry. It is strange that the Minister should seek, as one of his priorities, to try to back out of this arrangement in favour of the unions as his principal constituency, the one he should be addressing, is the primary production area of Australia. We have only to look at the rural package that was brought into this chamber a fortnight ago to see how little the Minister thinks of his primary industry constituents. We have only to look at his answer to a question during Question Time in connection with the sugar industry to see that he is prepared to walk away yet again from a promised $54m underwriting of the sugar industry. He is treating not only the sugar industry but also the beef industry with contempt in bringing this matter into this chamber and trying to justify it. I believe that the Minister's credibility is on the line more so than the orders he seeks to introduce.

I believe that what Australia wants at the moment as far as exports are concerned is a market in which we can prove to overseas consumers that we are reliable. The Mudginberri dispute smashed that completely. Agreements could not be entered into and contracts could not be fulfilled. The stain of the unions on Australia's reputation for reliability has spread.

Our labour costs need to be competitive. Mudginberri would have given us that competitiveness. It would have given us labour costs that were of benefit to the worker and also to the employer. Productivity was also a feature of the contract with Pendarvis and his men and would have increased. The Minister is trying to prop up a union case and he knows that the union is mainly to blame for other costs exporters face, such as interest rates, fuel costs and inflation. It is interesting to note that while the Minister is fiddling around with these orders to save the union movement, our inflation rate is on the way up, whereas those of our competitors are on the way down. That is another problem faced by our producers.

The export industry does not enjoy a free float of the dollar. The dollar has been regulated, again in accordance with the wishes of the union movement. It is interesting to note that the group which should have been consulted on this matter, the National Farmers Federation, was the first group in Australia that was prepared to take up a cause for an employer and fight it through the courts. It is also interesting to note that the Pendarvises of Mudginberri have not lost a case they have put through court, either the Federal Court of Australia or common law, yet they are still in a loss situation. The National Farmers Federation was prepared to support them all along the line. The National Farmers Federation is totally opposed to the orders that were originally brought into the Senate. I believe that it is just as opposed to the orders that are now being introduced into this chamber.

Again I ask: What sort of consultation was there with the NFF, if it is still in disagreement with the Government on this issue? I ask the Government what chance it feels it has of being in a better position after these orders have passed through the Senate. I believe that there is now no better case being spelt out than there was at the time of the introduction of the original orders. I believe that the Senate will and should resist the Minister's attempts to have these changes made, which we understand will be a direct abrogation of his responsibilities and duties. It is for that reason that I seconded the motion for the disallowance of the orders.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.
That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The humble Petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
We deplore the tax threshold of $5100, as the proposal adversely affects welfare recipients and low income earners.
We urge that the figure be $7500 to enable these citizens to have some chance to live with dignity.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Medicare Office, Wyong, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the fact that the lack of a Medicare Office in Wyong is seriously inconveniencing the residents of Wyong Shire.
Your petitioners therefore request that a Medicare Office is established in Wyong as soon as possible.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain electors of Australia respectfully sheweth:

That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine human and civil rights in Australia; will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States Rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth.

Your Petitioners humbly pray that: The Parliament rejects these Bills; abolishes the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain electors of the Division of Gwydir respectfully sheweth:

That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine human and civil rights in Australia; will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States Rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Additional Nuclear Reactor at Lucas Heights, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That they oppose the construction of any additional nuclear reactor at the Australian Atomic Energy Establishment at Lucas Heights in N.S.W., or any site within Australia.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government of Australia will not construct an additional nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights or within Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Additional Nuclear Reactor at Lucas Heights, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Sutherland Shire and New South Wales respectfully showeth: That they oppose the construction of any additional nuclear reactor at the Australian Atomic Energy Establishment at Lucas Heights in N.S.W.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government of Australia will not construct an additional Nuclear Reactor.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Private Health Insurance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth:
That we the undersigned are totally opposed to any taxation change which involves a tax on Health Fund contributions, health charges or benefits;

That we are already required to pay a 1 per cent levy to partly finance the Medicare scheme and that we would regard any further taxation of our health insurance arrangements as unfair and unreasonable;
That therefore we urge the Government to ensure that there is no taxation on illness and no special taxation on those who seek to insure themselves against the cost of private health care.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectifully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Namibia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: that the humble petitioners respectfully believe that the representatives in Australia of the African National Congress of South Africa (ANC) and of the South West African People's Organisation of Namibia (SWAPO) should not have to suffer unending financial problems related to the cost of rent, food and clothing, and the maintenance of two small offices run on the most austere basis.
Your petitioners therefore pray and urge Australian Government provision of:
1. Official recognition of the ANC and SWAPO as the legitimate representatives of the people of South Africa and Namibia;
2. Financial support to the offices and representatives of the ANC and SWAPO to promote the anti-Apartheid cause in Australia;
3. Additional financial support for the official representatives of the ANC and SWAPO to assist the humanitarian needs of Namibian and South African Refugees who are victims of Apartheid;
4. Scholarships for South African and Namibian refugees. These to be provided through the ANC and SWAPO education departments.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned petitioners, call upon the Australian Parliament to set up strong national Aboriginal land-rights legislation. We call upon Parliament to establish this legislation in line with the five principles of ALP Party Policy and to use its powers to over-ride states which do not comply with the legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: First Home Owners Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's proposed cutbacks in funding for the ``First Home Owners Scheme'', that the House of Representatives undertake to oppose such a move, in regard to its effect on young married couples in the community.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should undertake measures to restore the level of payments previously available under the Scheme.
And yout petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Horticultural Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned that Australia's important horticultural industry is being severely disadvantaged by unnecessarily rising production costs.

Many Federal and State Government regulations, excessive taxes and charges are damaging the ability of horticultural growers to maintain supplies of food and plant products to Australian families at a realistic cost. Widespread unemployment will result if horticultural producers are further depressed.

The undersigned humbly petition the Parliaments of Australia, its States and Territories, to take all measures within their powers to reduce the burden of imposed costs and regulation, allowing Australian horticultural growers to develop production potential so the nation, as a whole, can share the benefits of the resulting growth and prosperity.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's proposal to bring about a reduction in the amount payable under the present Family Allowance Scheme, that the House of Representatives assembled oppose such a move, on the evidence of its impact upon the family unit.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek to restore payments to the former level.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That deterioration of the total global environment is continuing at an increasing rate; that important environmental resources vital to human livelihood such as trees, soil and water are decreasing at an alarming rate; that there is a need for educating all people to assume a greater responsibility for the conservation sustainable use and maintenance of vital resources; that dynamic and active initiatives are needed to conserve and renew the total environment; and that protecting, conserving and repairing the Earth can unite all people and nations in co-operative action for survival.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will propose to the United Nations General Assembly at its 41st Session in September 1986 that 1988 be proclaimed the ``First International Earth Repair Year'' (FIERY) as a vital action to ignite global co-operation for Worldpeace.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Cards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

This petition of Australian residents shows that we strongly oppose the introduction of the ``Australia Card'' or any form of compulsory identity cards. We believe that the introduction of Identity cards will erode civil liberties; will create an increased risk of invasion of privacy; and will not result in any significant increase in Government revenue.
We call on the Parliament to immediately reject any proposal for the introduction of compulsory Identity cards.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows that:
in this International Year of Peace, 1986, the world needs a Nuclear Test Moratorium by the United States, the Soviet Union, France and other nuclear-testing powers
that such a Moratorium would create a favourable climate and basis for the negotiation of a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
that such a Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty would-
be the first vital step to nuclear disarmament
impede the development of new nuclear weapons
decrease the reliance upon an unstable nuclear strategy
inhibit the spread of nuclear weapons
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Australian Government be urged to:
1. Use its influence with the United States Government to encourage it to join the moratorium on nuclear testing begun by the Soviet Union on 6 August 1985.
2. Use its influence in all forums to encourage other nuclear nations to join the Nuclear Test Moratorium.
3. Use its influence in all forums to encourage non-nuclear nations to demand the establishment of a Nuclear Test Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons Tests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; and, to the Australian Government.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that a comprehensive ban on all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time would be a vital first step towards:
inhibiting the addition of more and more sophisticated and destabilising nuclear weapons to the world's arsenals;
arresting the extension of the arms race to outer space;
upholding the provisions of existing treaties and agreements.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:

1. The Australian Government (a) take new initiatives to encourage all member states of the United Nations-especially the governments of nuclear weapon states-to conclude at an early stage a treaty banning all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time; (b) call on all nuclear weapon states to declare an immediate moratorium on all nuclear weapon tests pending conclusion of a CTB.
2. All Federal Members of Parliament and Senators make strong representations to the Australian Government to act towards these goals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Price Control
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.

Our alarm with the continued spiralling cost of commodities, brought about we believe, by the monopolisation of retail outlets by multi- and transnational consortiums. We would ask the Government legislate effective price control and anti-monopoly measures to prevent further erosion of the living standards of the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, seek your most urgent action to rectify this deep concern to the community.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and local governments.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Gwydir electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Cowper electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of the State of Queensland respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and the present justice system in this country nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system of Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Forces, the State and Federal education systems, the independence of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn, the handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond Electorate respectfully showeth that:

The proposed capital gains tax penalises small business, discourages long-term investment, hinders capital formation and will freeze existing investment patterns and limits the investors' ability to adjust to changed market conditions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Immediately abandon its illconsidered capital gains tax proposal.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth that:
