Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Immediately abandon its ill-considered capital gains tax proposal.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That they strongly support the establishment of the Western Sydney State University as recommended in the Parry Report and call upon the House to establish the Western Sydney State University in conjunction with the New South Wales Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That they strongly support the establishment of the Western Sydney State University as recommended in the Parry Report and call upon the House to establish the Western Sydney State University in conjunction with the New South Wales Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has announced its intention to present the Title Deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, currently the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985,

Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government has no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in this manner,

Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but is handing over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia,

Whereas it is pursuing this policy making it a crime for most white and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (i.e. set aside for separate development), contrary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia,
Whereas Australian citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to prevent this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia,
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Fisher respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has purported to present the Title Deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, in reality the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985,

Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government had no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in such a disgraceful manner,

Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but purported to hand over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia,

Whereas it is pursuing this policy making it a crime for most white and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (i.e. set aside for separate development), contrary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia,
Whereas Australian citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to reverse this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia,
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully request that:
The worlds resources be redirected to the relief of human suffering, starvation, poverty and disease.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Stop spending taxpayers money on self promotion through high cost high profile but superficial policy on nuclear disarmament and make a genuine bi-partisan commitment to positive and practical policies designed to achieve progressive world-wide nuclear disarmament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor Government's productivity-superannuation accord with the ACTU and its support of the superannuation claims of the trade union movement will create an imbalance in industrial power and distort the future development of the Australian economy.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Reject the superannuation claim of the trade union movement, and allow superannuation to develop without trade union domination.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain electors of Dawson shows that the proposed Bill of Rights:
overlooks basic rights concerning union membership, education, and private property,
is a basis for massive intrusion into State responsibilities,
establishes a Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission with powers similar to a Court but without accepted legal procedures and protections for the accused, and
provides no avenue of appeal against decisions of the HR&EOC.

The petition further shows that fundamental protection of human rights is already to be found in the Courts, in tolerance, in fair play, belief in democratic institutions, and in support for rule of law.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament will not allow the Australian Bill of Rights Bill to pass into law.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Tasmania respectfully showeth:
1. That in its present form the Australian Bill of Rights 1985 does not represent the reasoned opinions of public opinion.
2. The Bill denies more rights than it upholds.
3. That one day's debate in the House of Representatives was insufficient time for our elected representatives to debate legislation which will control our lives indefinitely.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
(a) That the Bill lay before the House to allow reasoned debate by the electors of Australia.
(b) That our elected representatives be allowed to consider the Bill without haste.
(c) That any divisions on the Bill be recorded by a conscience vote by Members and not on Party lines.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Fringe Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled:
We, the undersigned petitioners of the electorate of Farrer, do respectfully show our opposition to the proposed Fringe Benefits Tax, as it applies to the purchase of company cars.
Such a tax will be an additional burden upon small businesses, and will adversely affect the Australian car industry, including component manufacturers.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation Radio Studio, Grafton
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of certain citizens of the North Coast of New South Wales, Australia, respectfully showeth:

That the community of Grafton and the Clarence Valley desire the retention of the A.B.C. Radio Studios in Grafton for the Second Regional Radio Network and pledge total support of Grafton City Council's submission on the Green Paper entitled `Discussion Paper-Second Regional Radio Network for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation'.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will sympathetically look at the problems of all these people in northern New South Wales and that the responsible Minister will take the necessary action to ensure the retention of the A.B.C. Radio Studio in Grafton and heed the submission of Grafton City Council in response to the Green Paper entitled `Discussion Paper-Second Regional Radio Network for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Shire of Caboolture situated in the Federal Division of Fisher, Queensland, respectfully showeth:

that the present Commonwealth funding for day care facilities for child care in the Shire of Caboolture is totally inadequate to meet the growing demands of the district which is one of the fastest growing areas in Queensland and Australia.

that the funding for Aboriginal and migrant child care facilities is disproportionately high in comparison to growth areas such as Caboolture which are seriously disadvantaged under present Federal Government funding guidelines.

that there is an apparent excessive number of places for child care funding in Canberra and the Australian Capital Territory, while there is a lack of these places in Caboolture, Queensland, and other areas remote from the Capital.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
1. That rapid growth areas such as the Shire of Caboolture be given special consideration in the allocation of funding.
2. That such funding be made available at similar levels to that provided to migrant and Aboriginal communities.
3. That funding in Canberra and the Australian Capital Territory be reduced to a level appropriate to reasonable requirements and that the funds be reallocated to localities of greater need.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Service, Somerset Dam, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of certain citizens of Somerset Dam in the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
That we object to the hasty and ill conceived relocation of the public telephone facility at Somerset Dam on the grounds that-
(a) it does not meet the needs of the area;
(b) it does not have the support of the local Community;
(c) it is open to vandalism;
(d) it is poorly lit.

Your petitioners therefore request that: A further public telephone service be made available at the previous location or if this is not possible that the present public telephone service be resited at its previous location.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Entertainment Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth that:

The total disallowance by the Hawke Labor Government of tax deductibility for entertainment and hospitality expenses will unfairly penalise Australian business and cost thousands of jobs for young and unskilled people.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Abandon its total ban on entertainment expenses and allow tax deductibility for legitimate and necessary expenses.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Loan Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
that the current policy pursued by the Hawke Government is causing an intolerable increase in home loan interest rates beyond the capacity of families to pay.
that consequently this policy is causing grave hardship throughout Australia and is contributing to social problems and the breakup of the family unit.
that unless the Government act urgently the Australian dream of home ownership is fast becoming shattered for many of our citizens.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Government make home loan interest rates tax deductible therefore alleviating the present crippling burden of current high interest rates on home owners and home buyers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Fisher respectfully showeth:

That we deplore the discriminatory tax proposals as outlined in the Government's ``White Paper'' and the Government's preferred option on proposed new and widened tax proposals as so outlined, namely:
Capital Gains tax
Hidden Death tax described as ``Capital Gains tax after death''
Gift Tax
Increased Company tax
Employer taxes on employees' employment benefits.
All such taxes will discriminate against and inhibit progress, growth and employment throughout the nation.

They will attack hardworking people who have built up their assets; they will discourage thrift; they will inhibit development; they will treat unfairly all who plan for the future; they will cause trouble and expense in arriving at the value of their assets; they will discourage industry and punish achievement.
We ask that the tax proposals be rejected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Depreciation on Buildings
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher respectfully showeth that:
The ban by the Hawke Socialist Government on negative gearing and restrictions on property depreciation will adversely affect thousands of disadvantaged people who rent their homes.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: End its ill-considered and discriminatory policy on rented property and allow depreciation on all buildings used to produce rental income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the Hawke Socialist Government be called upon to remove the unjust and cruel Assets Test;
That the Assets Test discriminates grossly against those people living on acreage blocks or in rural areas;
That the introduction of the Government's grab for the assets of senior citizens is condemned as un-Australian;
That the Government is requested to reconsider the Assets Test.

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Unionism

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: -Madam Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The concern for all Australians and their families in the failure of the Prime Minister and his Ministers to prevent the continuing decline in our international commodity trade.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We all recall that the current account deficit for March was $1,023m. It was the sixth successive month when the current account deficit was above $1 billion and it reflects an annual current account deficit this year of around $14 billion, the worst annual outcome ever. We know that on top of that the consumer price index increase of 2.3 per cent has produced an annual inflation rate of 9.2 per cent. That stands against the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average of 3.8 per cent, against our major trading partners average of 3.8 per cent and against the figures of 1.8 per cent for Japan and 0.7 per cent for West Germany in a month when we know that inflation in the United States of America for the second successive time was negative.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that this Government is the highest taxing government in peacetime history. We also know that our overseas deficit has reached an alarming level. Our overseas debt is now in excess of $77 billion, something in excess of $20,000 per family. We know that advisers to the Government and academics have seen that changes must be introduced. Professor Tom Valentine of Macquarie University at yesterday's International Association of Economics and Business Management Students conference stated:
. . . the Reserve Bank's policy of using interest rates to support the Australian dollar in the hope that the current account deficit will fall through the so-called J-curve effect has not succeeded.
He also said that currency support through interest rate control is demonstrably unviable and that it is essential that there be:
. . . the promotion of wage flexibility and restraint, and the encouragement of savings.

We find that even when the much vaunted Treasurer (Mr Keating) was overseas trying to talk up the economy those who listened to the words in London were more than a little sceptical. David Robins, an economist for London broker, Phillips and Drew, stated:
He-
he was talking about the Treasurer-
should have said how Australia is going to decrease the current account deficit . . .
What they could have done is not have an incomes policy and reduced the real wages in Australia to keep the competitive edge built up through the depreciation.
And having let the economy grow very quickly by spending government money, they have built in a large structural imbalance into the current account debt repayment.

Every economic statistic facing this Government as it goes into the 1986-87 Budget is disastrous. It is in that climate that, not unnaturally, we on this side of the House look towards the measures that the Government will pursue to try to correct the imbalance in the balance of payments and to see what it will do to correct the disastrous scene that faces not only the rural sector, small businessmen and home owners but also every Australian and every Australian family.

We listened with interest to the fact that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer for the first time in the three years of the Labor Government were going overseas supposedly to try to talk up the opportunities for Australian exports, to talk down the implications of the common agricultural policy in the European Economic Community and to ensure that the impact of the farm Bill in the United States was not as adverse as everyone predicted it would be. Indeed, even today, in the climate of all the things that are happening, we find the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) saying that Hawke's talks were essentially very successful.

Let us look at the reality. We opened this morning's newspaper to find the heading `United States attacks Australian wheat market as Hawke returns'. We saw headlines which unfortunately are backed by substance in the story. We have learned that Australia had expected to sell 400,000 tonnes of wheat to North Yemen this year and that the move by the United States, according to the new Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board, has already cost Australia an estimated $10m. We know that it is not just a matter of the North Yemen market. We know that last week the United States sold 50,000 tonnes of wheat to another Australian market-Jordan-and that it paid a subsidy of $US24 a tonne. We know that Egypt, which is Australia's current premier wheat market, has already had earmarked by the United States 350,000 tonnes of wheat which will be subsidised in order to establish a niche there.

The sales made so far under the United States Farm Bill program are aimed essentially at reducing the current stocks of 50 million tonnes of wheat. This year's harvest in the United States is expected to yield another 66 million tonnes and much of it will also be disposed of on the international market thanks to the subsidies of the United States and in spite of any representations the Government might have made. I think it is of interest that we were told by the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins), who is at the table, that the level of support by the United States as a result of his representations has been reduced to only $1 billion. In fact we all know that that is not so. It has now transpired that the level of subsidy will be at least $1.5 billion.

What is important as we look at the stories that the Government is spreading? Firstly, let us look at the North Yemen story because it is very illustrative of the problem that is facing our whole export sector. This morning we heard that the Special Minister of State (Mr Young), at a Press briefing following a Caucus meeting, stated:
The Government knew about the American wheat tender but had reason to believe that it would not be accepted. Had we known that it would turn out this way we could have done something about it.

That is a bit like the argument last week between the Minister for Primary Industry and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh)-the right hand does not know what the left hand is doing. Today we had an explanation in the House that this was not a matter of taking away from Australia's trade; it was all a product of misunderstanding. Simply, the EEC had apparently sold something like 132,000 tonnes of flour to North Yemen and the United States sale was not a replacement for Australian wheat trade to North Yemen but a replacement for European Community flour. I wish to goodness that the Special Minister of State had listened to the Minister for Primary Industry at Caucus, or perhaps we really are getting the truth from the Special Minister of State. Let me repeat it. The Special Minister of State said:
The Government knew about the American wheat tender but had reason to believe that it would not be accepted.

In other words what is happening is that this Government has supposedly been overseas trying to apply in some way pressure against the United States and the European community, but the result is demonstrably to the detriment of Australian exporters and is certainly adversely impacting on Australia's balance of payments. We should remember that the North Yemen story is not new. Indeed, back in January this year we learnt that the export enhancement program of the United States had already cost Australian farmers $1.32m in lower prices on a wheat sale to North Yemen and that was in spite of earlier assurances.

We know that this does not apply to just grain. Let us face reality. We know that the United States farm Bill is also disastrous for cotton. The floor has been pulled out of the market. The export price for Australian cotton has already been reduced by about $100 a bale, from about $300 a bale down to about $200 a bale. We know that, with the very large stocks of cotton in the United States, it is likely that the cotton market will crash further.

Only today, I have learned that we will suffer not only in relation to grain on the Middle East markets and in relation to cotton on world markets but also in relation to rice in Papua New Guinea. Let us face it, cotton is not a product that the European Community is selling and rice is certainly not a product that the European Community sells into Papua New Guinea. Indeed, it would seem, as far as the Papua New Guinea position is concerned, that a company called Rice Industries Pty Ltd of Australia currently exports all the rice required by Papua New Guinea from the Australian rice growing industry, and we have heard that, as a result of subsidies in the United States, henceforth something like 50,000 to 60,000 tonnes of rice is to be shipped into that market at the rate of about 4,000 to 5,000 tonnes a month. We learn from the American Embassy that the United States Government has passed a new law to subsidise rice farmers in the United States, and we know that Thailand, the world's largest rice exporter, has called the United States plan a declaration of war. Angry protests have certainly been heard from India as well.

So the situation is that every major commodity has been affected in some way by the United States approach and we know that the Prime Minister and the Minister at the table, the Minister for Trade, have been abroad supposedly to do something about that approach. Let us look at exactly what has happened. When the Minister for Trade came back to Australia from his trip to the United States we were told that the changes he thought he had been able to secure in Washington meant that the consequences of the United States farm Bill would not be as disastrous as they might have been had those changes not been developed. He made that statement on 18 February last. He said that as a result of his efforts there would not be a price deterioration in Australian exports. On 20 February he came into the House and said that in the months ahead the Government would be working closely with the United States Administration, with affected developing country agricultural exporters and with countries in our own region to ensure that the mandate for a new negotiating round in the General Agreement on Tariff and Trade would proceed so that Australian exporters would not be affected. The reality is that none of those promises has come true. Indeed, the Minister for Trade said:
The undertakings I have received from the US Administration will help to ensure a better deal this year and next for Australian farmers.
What do we learn this morning about wheat sales to Yemen? United States action has already cost Australian wheat growers $10m.

What is the position as far as the Department of Trade is concerned? This is where our concern lies. First, Ministers have gone abroad, following which they have told us the good news story about how effective they have been. We all know the reality of the Prime Minister's change in attitude towards the attack by the United States on Libya to try to control international terrorism. We all know how in this House he refused to say anything about terrorism being something the world should be concerned about and refused to come out and endorse the American action. He got over to Washington and we finally found that he gave unequivocal support for the United States action. Why? Because supposedly he was going to get guarantees from the United States Administration. However, as Wallace Brown said in the Courier-Mail of 19 April in an article headed `Time to look at the bottom line', Mr Reagan has inserted a five-word rider to the assurances he gave the Australian Prime Minister. The rider is `to the extent we can'.

The reality is that this Government has lost its effective bargaining power. First, it has lost it because the Department of Trade has been restructured to place emphasis on manufacturing industry. I have not time to read all the extracts I have, but I draw the attention of honourable members to the House of Representative Hansard of 13 May last, at page 2151, when the Minister said:
. . . the Department is looking particularly to some manufacturing and service industries, which embody our comparative advantage and which are most likely to achieve export success quickly.
He also said:
While we can expect improved returns for commodity exports, the boost to exports is potentially more powerful outside the traditional commodity trades, in services and manufacturing.

This Minister has removed the ability of the Australian Trade Commissioner Service to place particular emphasis on commodity and mineral exports. Without that emphasis there is no earthly chance of our being able to achieve redress in our balance of payments, for those major agricultural and mineral exports still are the basis of Australia's export revenue.

The reality is that the Minister at the table not only has lost his credibility abroad but also has demonstrably lost his credibility at home. We know of his succession of misdemeanours, including his involvement in Coomel Pty Ltd and a bottom of the harbour company. We know of the conflict of interests he demonstrably had when he failed to reveal his association with a Bell Resources Ltd shareholding, and we know that his membership of a Cabinet sub-committee has placed him in an impossible position in terms of the credibility he now enjoys not only amongst his Cabinet colleagues but amongst those with Caucus. We know of his intervention in Department of Trade appointments to Trade Commissioner posts. We have heard and are still hearing of his variation to the story regarding his involvement in seeking the appointment of Mr Emanuel Klein, from the office of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), to the post in Milan instead of the Senior Trade Commissioner, Mr Tom Walton. We know of his involvement in appointing that other Australian Labor Party stooge, Mr Alan Oxley, to the post in Geneva.

We know that Mr David Combe-that man about whom diabolical things were said by Mr Justice Hope; the man who was seen by Mr Justice Hope, when heading a royal commission, as having involved himself in such a way as to prejudice Australia's security-was appointed by this Minister to the post of Australian Trade Commissioner in Vancouver, the post from which Canada exports most of its grain to those markets for which Australia principally competes. What happened? The United States found it necessary to change the ground rules of that appointment, so that Mr Combe no longer enjoys the status that his predecessor enjoyed. We need to understand that before Mr David Combe took up that appointment another person was already appointed, but that situation was changed by this Minister.

We know that Mr Peter Steedman, a failed member of this House, working under the Minister is in charge of that disastrous Priority One: Young Australia program. We know that Michael Delaney, the former Press Secretary to the Minister for Trade, is head of the drug campaign which, sadly, looks as though it also will be a disaster. None of the officials who are working with those affected by drugs have given any endorsement to the program. Sadly, they all accept that the Minister at the table has really not been able to give them someone who is able to give the leadership that the drug campaign deserves.

Neither in the manner of the Minister's appointment of trade commissioners nor in the exercise of his responsibilities can the Australian community have any faith that the international problems of this nation will be redressed, and the Minister himself and the Government will suffer as a result.

They are already facing considerable problems because of this Government's internal economic policies which have led to the highest interest rates since the great depression. SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, Australia has not only rising inflation but in fact it will continue to be a problem because the wage system that this Government has taken from the ACTU will lock us into a high inflation rate. As has been already pointed out, this Government has failed to address the problems that are facing Australia in its lack of competitiveness in world markets. It has failed to tackle the real problems at home of high interest rates and inflation. It has also failed to come up with a real wage policy. I think today's matter of public importance is all about the Government's failure to get results, the failure of the Minister for Trade and the failure of the Prime Minister. They have failed to prevent a continuing decline in our international commodity trade. In fact, I would suggest that the Prime Minister should hot foot it over to Bali right now to see President Reagan-even if the Indonesians do not want to see the Prime Minister there-and get the real assurances that he has tried to tell us that he got when he came back from the United States. The Prime Minister should admit that he has failed and should go back this time to do his job properly so that he can get it right. Then and only then can the Prime Minister expect the recognition of his efforts that he so desperately craves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In many ways this is an absolutely remarkable matter of public importance because it comes from the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair). The Leader of the National Party-this matter of public importance concerns trade-is perhaps best known as the real architect of protectionism and of restrictive trade in terms of international trade in this Parliament. Indeed, as I rise to speak to this matter of public importance, I cannot help but experience the sensation that we are in a sort of time warp because, really, this matter of public importance would have been far more appropriate and far more relevant to Australia had it been moved in this Parliament five or 15 years ago. I say that because the difficulties that Australia has with trade problems are not something that have suddenly occurred in the past six months, one year or two years; they have been ongoing problems which were most manifest as a result of the policies of the Liberal-National Party coalition. Of course, they were years when the Leader of the National Party-as he is now-played a prominent role as both Minister for Primary Industry and Minister for Trade.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is, as I have said, that while Australia's trade performance has been difficult over recent years, it is really a matter which has been fundamental in Australia for the last 30 years. The difficulties that we now experience are very much in every way a legacy of the inept policies of the Liberal and National parties, which had stewardship in this country for 27 of the past 30 years. So, it is the height of hypocrisy for the Opposition parties to move this matter of public importance today. I will make a few points about what happened to Australia over the last 30 years in terms of international trade.

The first point is that our share of world exports collapsed from 2.6 per cent to 1.2 per cent of the world market-a collapse of 50 per cent in real terms. We also slipped from eighth to twenty-third on the ranking of world exporters. In anybody's terms that is a dramatic reduction, a dramatic slip in our ranking of world exporters. There is a third point that is relevant, that is, between 1962 and 1981 Australian exports as a proportion of gross domestic product actually fell from 14 per cent to 13 per cent. The relevance of that is that worldwide in many countries-including Europe, North America, Japan, West Germany and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development as a whole-the export proportion was actually increasing by a magnitude of about 50 per cent.

It is really as a result of the economic incompetence of the Opposition parties that Australia's standard of living absolutely and relatively declined during that period. In terms of per capita income, we slipped from fifth in the order of the OECD ladder in 1950 to twelfth by the time the McMahon Government was thrown out in 1972. So, it is a really remarkable assertion that the Opposition parties make today that Australia has trading problems and that those problems are the result of this Government, because not only did the Opposition leave us with that legacy of 30 years of poor growth, at the same time it failed to exploit the magnificent trading opportunities which were available right at our door step. In the last 20 years, economic growth in the newly industrialised countries of the western region has been two to three times that of Europe and the OECD as a whole. In fact, the growth in the region's demand for products has been three to four times higher. Yet the shame of this and the shame of this motion today is that Australia's share of that market under the stewardship of those failed men opposite went backwards. We went backwards from 7 per cent to 4 per cent in the years prior to 1983. None of that has happened under this Government.

There is nothing new about Australia's trading performance; it has all occurred over the last 30 years. In fact, if one looks at the volume and the value of exports that have been produced under the policies of this Government, one will see that when we came to government in 1982-83 there was $20 billion in exports from Australia; the figure in 1984-85 was $29 billion; and the figure this year will be more than $32 billion in exports. That is an increase of 50 per cent in exports. It is absurd and the height of nonsense for the Opposition to come in here today and allege that this Government is in any way responsible for a decline in world markets. In fact, quite the contrary is true because under this Government, particularly in the commodity area, our share of world markets in terms of volume has increased. If anyone on the Opposition benches has an immediate, overnight, simple, quick fix solution to the problem of prices for wheat or agricultural products, he is a better person than us. The fact is that members opposite do not have the solution and they never had the solution. Members opposite could not get an increase in the share of exports when they were in government, but we have been able to do that under our Government. They are some of the facts of the matter that are pertinent to this debate.

The second speaker for the Opposition made some points about our trade, particularly in agricultural commodities. I will look at two areas, because I think they are highly relevant and not only to total exports-because agricultural commodities provide about 40 per cent of our total exports-but also very important to primary producers throughout Australia. I will look at two areas: The marketing of rural products and what this Government has done in that area and, secondly, what we have done to increase and improve our trading prospects. When we came to Government, in the marketing area we faced a situation in which rural marketing organisations had been under seige. The efficiency of the Australian Dairy Corporation had been seriously questioned and the Australian Wheat Board's accounts were in an unacceptable and unaccountable state. In many ways initiative in many corporations had been stifled by red tape. We had agro-political conflicts which were destroying and diminishing the confidence of our statutory marketing authorities. Nowhere were those difficulties more pronounced than in the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. Under this Government all of those problems have been resolved. We have swept away the old AMLC and we have replaced it with a new efficient marketing authority. We have also provided an extra $7m in Government funding for assistance for AMLC funding. (Quorum formed)

In the minute that is left to me I point out that during this debate on trade policy, which is important to Australia, only three members of the Opposition have been present, while many Government members, of course, have been present to support this contribution to the debate. The point was raised regarding what we have done for exports in this country. We have done everything we can and we will continue to do everything we can in the future. We have restructured the Department of Trade. We have put in place new marketing initiatives. My colleague, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), knows that we have done that. In the rural area, the agricultural area, we have reformed agricultural marketing councils. We have reduced real labour unit costs in this country to the lowest level for five years. The level of industrial disputes has been reduced to its lowest level for 17 years. We have seen a devaluation of 25 per cent, which has given a new competitive edge to exporters and importers in this country. That is what we have done for trade and employment. It puts paid to this lie which has been generated by members of the Opposition. In 30 years of their government our competitive performance was eroded to one of the poorest performances in the world. It has been up to this Government to try to turn that around, to restore this position and generate new opportunities in Australia.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I present the Committee's report on proposals for the variations on the plan of layout of the city of Canberra and its environs, the 87th series, together with a copy of minutes of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Government members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable members for their enthusiastic response. The report I have just tabled reports on the 16 items in the 87th series of variations to the plan or layout of the city of Canberra. The Committee recommends approval of all 16 variations. The Committee, in considering these variations, examined 21 submissions and took evidence from 17 witnesses appearing as individuals and representing various organisations. The cost involved in the proposals dealt with is approximately $6m. I wish to comment on only four of the variations.

SPEECH.PARA: Variation 9 provides the road layout for the Bruce Ridge West housing estate. An objection received by the Committee emphasised the need to oblige developers to comply with development conditions on the site. It was alleged that even though the National Capital Development Commission indicted significant effort was made to ensure a high landscape quality, such development conditions were difficult to enforce. The Committee hopes that with the impending transfer of land administration the National Capital Development Commission, development conditions will be closely monitored. In approving the variation the Committee urges the NCDC to examine the possibility of increasing the size of cluster developments to take full advantage of the housing potential on the site.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to fix up the roads in the ACT?

—This is all about roads. Variation 12 proposes the provision of a trunk cyclepath from Streeton Drive in Holder to the existing Yarramundi Reach cyclepath at Lady Denman Drive. Members of the Parliament who cycle to this Parliament will find this of great use.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee received an objection to the alignment of the proposed cyclepath from the Canberra Lakes Pony Club. The club was concerned that the route would prevent access to an area known as the `sandpits' and that the proximity of the cycleway to the cross country jumping course would create potential hazards.

The Committee noted that the NCDC had made various concessions to the club, including revising its original alignment proposal, undertaking to erect a length of equestrian fencing and indicating its willingness to construct an alternative sandpit area in another location. The Committee was also made aware that most of the area used by the club, with the exception of two small blocks on short term lease, is unleased Commonwealth land. The Committee believes the rights of other groups wishing to enjoy the visual and scenic character of the river corridor must be recognised. It considers the proposed alignment to be appropriate and approves the variation.

Variation 14 provides for roads off Learmonth Drive and Kambah Pool Road in Tuggeranong to permit the area to be developed as a golf course and associated housing. I am sure the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will be interested in that. Objections received by the Committee focused on anticipated traffic problems and potential environmental hazard to the Murrumbidgee River. The NCDC, on request, supplied the Committee with traffic estimates which indicate that the development will not generate a marked increase in vehicle numbers. The Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment has also examined the proposal. It has written to the developer of the Murrumbidgee Country Club setting out measures and conditions which should be included in the development to protect the Murrumbidgee River and its surroundings and to maintain the safety and amenity of the existing residential area adjacent to the proposed golf course. The developer has indicated he will comply with these requirements.

The Committee wishes to be briefed at a later date on progress on the development and the extent to which the development conditions have been complied with. The Committee is anxious to ensure that there be a green belt maintained at the residential end of the golf course with no further blocks developed at a later date. It would also like to ensure that there be no concessional element in the lease price due to the location of the residential development in the same area as the golf course. The Committee approves the variation, noting NCDC planning intentions to develop the whole area for residential housing if the golf course proposal were not to proceed.

Variation 15 provides for a network of roads off Bugden Avenue in Fadden to enable the area to be developed for residential blocks, water pollution control ponds and open space. Due to significant local resident interest in this proposal, the Committee undertook a site inspection, with NCDC officers, residents representing the Fadden Residents Action Group and individual residents in attendance. The Committee received an extensive submission from the resident action group as well as several individual submissions. Submissions generally opposed the proposal, although two favoured the development. Major concerns raised in objection related to inadequate public notification and inaccurately conveyed information regarding the extent and exact location of the development. A second major problem identified was that of traffic flows and access of vehicles, including buses, to existing roads opposite the development and into the development site itself.

In relation to the provision of information about development intentions to residents, the Committee is satisfied that initial purchasers were made aware that at some future time section 349 would be developed in part. Problems arise in relation to subsequent purchasers where estate agents may not have provided this information. However, the Committee is of the view that it is the responsibility of buyers themselves to inquire into the nature of surrounding areas before making a purchase. There appears to be substance to the claim that signs marking the designated Mount Wanniassa-Canberra Nature Park were moved and may have misled residents about the exact location of the nature park and thus the area available for development. However, the area originally designated for development has been reduced and the total area available for recreation and open space is significant.

The Committee is concerned that the volume of traffic already generated in the area will be compounded by vehicles arriving and leaving the proposed residential area. It believes that a roundabout should be constructed at the Sternberg Crescent and Bugden Avenue intersection to alleviate some of the major traffic problems in the area. Recognition is also given to the restricted footpaths on Bugden Avenue and the Committee supports the Commission's proposal to construct a pedestrian footpath along the western section. Further support is given to a proposal to increase the width of the collector road in the proposed new subdivision from 7.5 metres to 9 metres to allow buses to operate up Bugden Avenue from Sternberg Crescent.

The Committee recognises that opposing this proposed development would be seen as a precedent for preventing the total suburban land release program and would thereby impede the Commission's attempts at urban consolidation. This would be contrary to the Committee's thinking on the future development of land in the Australian Capital Territory. The Committee approves the variation.
