DEBATE.TITLE: FUTURES INDUSTRY BILL 1986[COGNATE BILLS:FUTURES INDUSTRY (FEES) BILL 1986COMPANIES AND SECURITIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (FUTURES INDUSTRY) BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 April, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate this Bill concurrently with the Futures Industry (Fees) Bill 1986 and the Companies and Securities Legislation Amendment (Futures Industry) Bill 1986. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The three Bills before the House are the Futures Industry Bill 1986, the Futures Industry (Fees) Bill 1986 and the Companies and Securities Legislation Amendment (Futures Industry) Bill 1986. These Bills have been agreed to by the parties to the formal agreement under which the companies and securities legislation of this country is enacted and by which the co-operative scheme works. It has been agreed that the co-operative scheme should be extended to cover the regulation of the futures market. The Bills, if enacted, would apply in the Australian Capital Territory and there will be legislation in each of the States to give effect to the Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: Not a great deal is known about the Australian futures industry save by those who operate in that industry. It may surprise some honourable members to know that the Sydney Futures Exchange Ltd is in fact one of the major exchanges in the world. In looking at the 1985 annual report of the Sydney Futures Exchange, one can see that the volume of business transacted on the Exchange, leaving aside the American markets, is major. If one looks at the top 10 share index futures and options contracts in the world by volume in 1985, one sees that the leaders in trading in that area are by far the American exchanges, with the Chicago Board Options Exchange trading more than 90 million such contracts. The Sydney Futures Exchange is ninth on the list, trading 284,000 contracts. That is very much less but still significant, when one puts to one side the American activity, as the number of options traded by the London Stock Exchange of that kind is in fact less than those traded in Australia in 1985, that is, on the Sydney Futures Exchange.

Again, if one looks at the top 10 interest rates futures and options contracts in the world by volume in 1985, one sees that once again the American exchanges lead the way. But, aside from the eighth position, which is held by the London International Financial Futures Exchange, the ninth position is held by the Sydney Futures Exchange. It is, therefore, a very significant Exchange outside of the United States of America. The development of the business on the Sydney Futures Exchange and elsewhere in this country is of importance to our financial system and to its development.

The Sydney Futures Exchange is in fact the main futures exchange in Australia. There is one in Melbourne which has been started recently. The market in Australia has grown significantly in the past 10 to 15 years with an expansion of commodities dealt in and an expansion of the number of clients using the market. After changes to the banking regulations in December 1983, the futures market became accessible to international clients, which is a most important factor for its development. The Australian market is now significant in international terms at least partly because of its position in the international time zone, its ability to trade when European and North American exchanges are closed and also the fact that when, in particular, North Americans and the British wish to trade, they can trade on a market where English is the spoken language; that makes it very simply a simpler operation for them.

Not a great deal is known about the actual nature of futures contracts. It is worth while saying something about them. For that purpose I quote from a document which has been prepared by the Sydney Futures Exchange for the purpose of an application made to the Trade Practices Commission to point out the relevant features of futures contracts. The document points out:

Futures contracts are a particular form of forward contract. Futures contracts are recognised as being standardised instruments which call for delivery at a specified future date of a specified grade of a commodity at a price determined at the time at which the contract is made.
It goes on to point out:
Futures contracts differ from other forms of forward contracts in several important respects, viz

(a) Futures contracts are highly standardised, thus ensuring fungibility i.e. all futures contracts of a particular class are perfect substitutes for each other and obligations under the futures contract are readily transferable. Fungibility is a critical property of futures contracts in that it enables them to be treated as a trading vehicle. Forward contracts generally do not have this quality.
(b) Futures contracts are traded competitively by `open outcry' (a form of open auction) on an organised futures exchange, subject to the rules of the exchange. In general, forward contracts are not.

If one goes to the Sydney Futures Exchange, one sees exactly what is meant by `open outcry'; it is open outcry. I noticed when I visited that there were some women operators. I was told that the women operators are in fact coming more into favour because their voices are somewhat more piercing than the voices of men. I considered whether it was possible for an application to be made under discrimination legislation to have this situation redressed, but apparently it is one of the inherent qualities that women possess but men do not. I was also told that in America-I think it was the Chicago Futures Exchange but I might be wrong-the activity was so heavy that, in order to make sure that one got a place in what is known as the pit, one chose former football players as operators. One got big people down there so that they could actually find their way into the pit. It is a pretty exhausting kind of work. I understand that, after a few years, most people go on to do something else.

Let us look at the rationale for regulation. First of all, the Sydney Futures Exchange points out that there is a need to promote overseas investor confidence, that futures trading across international borders can be undertaken at a relatively low cost and is facilitated by the international integration of commodity and financial markets, and that competition is rife among exchanges around the world and a sound structure within which to trade is essential in promoting the Australian exchange. Next, the Sydney Futures Exchange points out that there is the proscription of a list of futures trading, there are protections for consumers of the market, and there is the factor that the market is a growing one. It is felt by the Exchange that a comprehensive regulatory framework is necessary if it is to grow and, in particular, if it is to attract the kind of outside interest we would like to see attracted to it. Remember that the futures market, as I understand it, in places such as Tokyo and Hong Kong, is less competitive and less sought after than the Sydney Futures Exchange. So anything that can be done to promote the Exchange should be done.

The Exchange points out that whilst the New South Wales Futures Markets Act, which amongst other things was passed in order to overcome problems that might have been encountered with the Gaming and Betting Act, provides some regulation, the regulatory structure of the industry remains largely for the industry itself. The present regulatory structure does not cover brokers who choose not to become members of the Sydney Futures Exchange. These brokers can still conduct Sydney Futures Exchange business through a member and are free to conduct business on behalf of Australian clients on overseas futures market. It is thought that recent failures of these brokers have reflected on the industry.

As an Opposition, our general view about regulation is that we should keep regulation to the minimum. But we think that, where the regulation is sought by the market itself and where the Bill is in substance supported by the market, that, as a general rule, provides a sound reason for regulation. There have been two exposure drafts of the present legislation. The exposure drafts have been commented on by the Sydney Futures Exchange and the Law Council of Australia. The major Bill which is presently before the House-I speak of the Futures Industry Bill-has been altered to take note of comments that have been made on the first and second exposure drafts. In saying that I am not suggesting that all criticisms have been taken up but quite a number have.

Let me say a few further things about the futures market. In the first place the futures market facilitates risk management. It has a sound economic function of providing a market mechanism for the allocation of risk. There may be other ways to insure against risk when one is dealing in commodities in particular but none so flexible and cost competitive. Futures contracts are highly liquid and are priced continually in competitive market-places. Futures markets also provide a mechanism for sharing information about supply and demand conditions because the market itself reflects supply and demand conditions. By so reflecting supply and demand conditions it gives the best possible information as to the conditions of the market. As has been said by Professor Franklin Edwards:

Futures markets provide two fundamental economic services. The first is that futures contracts provide price signals which can be used by the producers, processors, and distributors to allocate real resources. More specifically, futures prices may influence storage and inventory decisions and may exert an important influence on production decisions. This is their `price discovery' function. Futures markets are seen as an efficient collector, processor, and disseminator of information. In the absence of futures prices, each economic actor himself would have to devote the required time and expenditure necessary to collect and interpret the underlying economic information about demand and supply conditions. If futures markets perform their price discovery function sufficiently well, and they can be reasonably relied upon to do so, individuals can avoid most of the informational costs they would bear otherwise, since they can simply rely upon easily observable futures prices in making their decisions.
Professor Franklin Edwards goes on to say:
The second economic function of futures markets is to provide a market mechanism for the allocation of risk. This is their `hedging' function. There may be other ways to insure against risk-
as I said a few moments ago-
but none which is more flexible or less costly:

The Exchange performs those two economic functions. Before I turn to the Bills themselves I should say something briefly about the distinction between hedgers and speculators. Once again, I draw upon the exceedingly useful document of the Sydney Futures Exchange, which points out:

It is common to classify participants in futures markets as either ``hedgers'' or ``speculators''. Like most schemes of classification this oversimplifies a complex array of motives and trading strategies but is nevertheless useful. Regardless of a trader's motives for entering the futures market such trading brings with it certain risks.

In general terms hedgers are those traders who deal in both the relevant physical commodity and the futures market, and whose use of the futures market is predominantly intended to manage the risks associated with price fluctuations in the market for the physical commodity.
The Exchange points out:

Hedging generates benefits of two kinds. First there is the direct commercial benefit to the individual hedger himself which arises from his ability to handle greater volumes of a commodity at the same level of risk (or alternatively, handle the same volume at reduced risk). Secondly there are the benefits which flow more generally relating to improved allocative efficiency.
As to speculators the Exchange points out:
Speculators typically have no involvement in the physical market but trade futures solely to profit by correctly forecasting price movements.

The role of speculators may be summarised, firstly, as bearing the risks that hedgers seek to avoid and, secondly, as generating liquidity in the market, thereby making it a more effective hedging medium.

Turning now to the Bill, I point out that, to a very great extent, the Bills are aimed at client protection by ensuring that brokers and exchanges operate according to certain standards and safeguards and that the market in which they operate are orderly and fair. The Opposition supports the Bills and accompanying legislation and does not propose to move any amendments to them. As I said earlier, the Opposition recognises that the industry is in favour of the legislation and its speedy enactment. But the Opposition also realises that the legislation is likely to suffer teething problems in the early period of its operation. The Law Council of Australia has, for example, made some fairly detailed criticisms of the Futures Industry Bill which is now before the House. It is not easy at this stage to forecast how likely some of the difficulties raised by the Law Council are. Some of the difficulties the Law Council sees may not arise in practice. Difficulties may arise in practice which will be greater than the Law Council envisages. We all know that there are bound to be difficulties which no one at this stage has spotted, under Bills as complex as these.

Let me make certain points about the legislation which might be borne in mind as possible subjects of amendment in the future. These are very technical comments. Clause 4 (1), the definition of agreement, may need clarification to take account of the novation of futures contracts. In regard to clause 4 (1) it may well be useful to add a clause similar in terms to section 4 (5) of the Securities Industries Code to ensure that exempt brokers are exempt from all of the provisions of the legislation and not just the licensing requirements. As to clause 51, practice may show that the grounds upon which associations may have their approval by the ministerial council suspended or cancelled should be specified in the legislation itself.

I make the point that clause 85 (3) is an illustration of problems peculiar to the futures markets' severing of the contractual nexus. Effectively the contracts become, it may be said, a species of money or certainly a species of highly negotiable instrument. The question may be posed if a contract were rendered illegal at its formation by a contravention of a provision of the Act or, indeed, by a contravention of some other provision of an Act, which might go to the legality of the contract, can a subsequent party rely on the illegality to avoid his obligation? I should think that it was not intended that that was to be so. It is certainly of primary importance to the futures market that this kind of problem does not arise. Under clause 87, there are obligations on futures brokers to provide certain information to clients. Clause 87 provides:
A futures broker shall, before accepting a person as a client of the broker, give to the person-
(a) a document that-
(i) explains the nature of futures contracts;
(ii) explains the nature of the obligations assumed by a person who instructs a futures broker to enter into a futures contract;
(iii) sets out a risk disclosure statement in the prescribed form; and
(iv) sets out the specifications, and details of the essential terms, of each kind of futures contract in which the broker deals on behalf of clients; and
(b) a copy of each agreement into which the broker proposes, if the broker agrees to accept instructions from the person in relation to dealings in futures contracts, to require the person to enter.

Some practical problems may be associated with this provision. It may be considered and may prove to be overregulation. But let us remember that people who deal on futures markets are, for the most part, fairly sophisticated. In financial terms one is dealing with either hedgers or speculators. I should think that most people who get involved in the futures market know what the risks are and know what the market is about. If we are to develop a substantial international interest in this country it would be a pity if transactions were held up or simply were not entered into and other markets used by reason of the need to give to someone, who knows very well what the futures market is like and may have operated in the futures market for many years, a document setting out the details provided by clause 87. If the clients are at the other side of the world, obviously enough there are difficulties. That is a matter to which I draw the Government's attention as something which may require to be adjusted if it appears that there are practical problems in the application of clause 87 not only to those resident outside an area where a futures exchange is conducted in this country, but also, more importantly, to those resident overseas.

Clause 116 deals with the application of fidelity funds, but it does not appear to deal with the problem of apportionment of responsibility where a broker is a member of more than one futures exchange or association. As a general comment there is some overlapping with the Securities Industries Code. Some of the areas of overlap have already been identified by the Law Council and more may become apparent as the legislation becomes operative. I would be interested in knowing whether the Government has carried out a detailed investigation of the co-relation between the two pieces of legislation. This seems to be particularly appropriate as the Securities Industries Code is currently undergoing a complete revision. Perhaps the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) can clarify my last point for me. Clause 45 (1) of the Bill provides:

A person shall not establish, maintain or provide, or assist in establishing, maintaining or providing, or hold himself, herself or itself out as maintaining or providing, a futures market that is neither a futures market of a futures exchange nor an exempt futures market.

I wonder whether it was intended to use the words `a futures market or a futures exchange'. I presume that phrase simply points to a market in a futures exchange. If that is so, no real problem seems to arise. Those are the matters to which I draw the attention of the House. As I said at the outset, the Bill is thought to be necessary. There have been two exposure drafts upon which there has been considerable comment. In practice problems may be encountered. I hope that the Government will take notice of any problems which may arise and will legislate to deal with them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Futures Industry Bill, the Futures Industry (Fees) Bill and the Companies and Securities Legislation Amendment (Futures Industry) Bill which we are debating concurrently at present introduce a number of controls and regulations into the futures industry. In particular-this was referred to by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender)-the legislation deals with a number of important prudential changes and reflects, to a very large extent, the fact that over the last 10 to 15 years Australia has entered into a situation in which trading in commodities and financial trading has become much more refined, much more complex and much more sophisticated. The futures market has developed in Australia as it has in other similar advanced Western countries and the time has arrived when it has become apparent, not only to operators within the market but also to State governments and certainly to the Commonwealth Government, that there is a need for regulations of this kind to be introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for North Sydney acknowledged the fact that the market had, to a very large extent, called for this legislation, and, of course, that is true. I hope that he included in the market not just the operators, the brokers, the large hedgers and the large speculators but also the small operators and the customers of the futures markets who, up until the present, have to a very large extent found themselves unfortunately in a position in which some of the smart operators in this area have been able to rip them off. So it is not just the market in terms of the large dominating influences, the large dominating operators; it is the market right across the board. Certainly demand has developed for legislation of this kind.

The development of the futures market in Australia has been quite interesting. It was only last year that the Sydney Futures Exchange had its twenty-fifth birthday-it was established in 1960 when it began trading in a single contract, wool. When it started trading in wool it was trading on a tiny trading floor in O'Connell Street, Sydney. Of course the market has undergone very significant development since then. The number of commodities that are now traded has grown to nine. They include agricultural commodities, precious metals, the present market leaders in financial futures, bank bills, bonds, United States dollars and the all ordinaries share price index. Over the last 10 years, particularly in more recent years, the most rapid development has taken place in connection with trading in financial futures. As I have said, the futures market in Australia has become quite highly developed, quite complex and quite sophisticated.

The honourable member for North Sydney also referred to at least one of the two very significant changes which took place last year as a result of deregulation. He referred to the removal of the exchange controls which had inhibited overseas trading by Australians and trading in the Sydney Futures Exchange by non-residents. Of course that means that the futures market in Australia has been exposed to international trading arrangements. The honourable member for North Sydney also drew attention, quite correctly, to the fortunate strategic position which we enjoy in Australia as a result of being an English speaking country and at the same time occupying a longitudinal time slot which sometimes makes it possible for exchange dealings of this kind to take place in Australia when markets in other countries have closed.

The other significant development which took place last year was the the abolition of fixed commission rates which have now been replaced by freely negotiated commissions between brokers and their clients. It has been an industry where a series of very significant and important developments have taken place. In May last year, at the time when the exchange turned 25 years of age, a very important introduction into its operation was exchange traded options. This is a very significant departure from the simple type of futures which had been traded previously in the Sydney Futures Exchange.

The introduction of exchange traded options gave the Australian market users at that time an unprecedented measure of flexibility in their trading and their risk management strategies. They confer on the buyer the right to buy or sell futures contracts at a predetermined price called the exercise price. The holder of one of those options has no obligation to do anything; he has the right just to buy or sell the futures at a set price. Under that arrangement a call option is an option to buy a futures contract while a put option is an option to sell a futures contract. The option itself is in the money, if it would be profitable to exercise it. The question of whether or not it would be profitable in the future for the person who buys those exchange traded options to exercise those options depends upon the changes which have taken place between the time he entered into the contract and the time that the option would no longer be available to him. The honourable member for North Sydney quoted someone who said that participation in the futures market is either by people who are engaged in hedging or people who are engaged in speculative activity. Even to a greater extent than normal stock markets in our metropolitan cities, the futures market is an area in which people are able to speculate. A fair amount of gambling takes place.

I think the background to this legislation is of particular interest. In June 1982 the Ministerial Council of the National Companies and Securities Commission-which is part of the co-operative scheme established in 1978 and known as the formal agreement under which the Commonwealth and each of the six States participate in all of the mechanical arrangements for the operation of the National Companies and Securities Commission on a national scale-resolved that a draft Bill regulating the futures industry should be prepared. What we are considering now is the final stage in the development of that consideration. In October 1984 the first exposure draft was available. It was very widely distributed and very widely considered and a number of suggestions were made by interested parties. Many of those suggestions, either in the first exposure draft or in the subsequent one of November 1985, have now been incorporated in the legislation that we are in the process of considering.

Over the range of operations within the futures market the legislation gives consideration to questions concerning appropriate inspection and investigation powers, the approval and regulation of futures exchanges and clearing houses, a system for the licensing of future brokers and others involved in the industry and a significant number of prudential controls and requirements which will be imposed by this legislation. As a result of this initiating legislation on the part of the Commonwealth at present, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) indicated this in his second reading speech, the other parties to the formal agreement-of course they are the six States and the two Territories following the inclusion of the Northern Territory recently-will introduce complementary legislation that will apply throughout Australia. The need to have a uniform regulatory system governing the futures industry in Australia was recognised by the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System in its report some years ago. As was indicated by the honourable member for North Sydney in his contribution, that has been endorsed by the Sydney Futures Exchange Ltd as well. So, there is widespread support for the proposals that are being considered.

I know that some concerns and some doubts have been expressed about the adequacy with which the particular activities or operations within the futures industry have been defined. Clause 4 of the legislation itself says that a `futures contract' means:
(a) an agreement that is, or has at any time been, an eligible commodity agreement or an adjustment agreement;
(b) a futures option; or
(c) a prescribed exchange-traded option,
but does not include-

and then goes on to identify a currency swap, an interest rate swap, a forward exchange rate contract and a forward interest rate contract. It indicates as well that the definition does not include an agreement that, at the time it was entered into, is included in a class of agreements prescribed for the purposes of that particular paragraph. Whether or not those concerns are legitimate and justified I am not certain. It may be possible for the Attorney-General, in summing up, to indicate what the present state of play is concerning our attitude towards the adequacy or otherwise of some of those definitions, particularly the definition concerning a futures contract.

I know that concern has been expressed about whether or not some things, such as life insurance policies and perhaps even the forward bullion markets, would be picked up and become subject to these regulations through the futures market. I am not sure about that, and I would be interested to hear any observations about it. Earlier this year Mr John Green, a partner in Dawson Waldron, said:
The futures industry is an industry with an intense magnetic attraction to the greedy, the naive and the dishonest,

He is an operator in the market; he is one of the people to whom reference was made by the honourable member for North Sydney. They are his comments, and to a very large extent he is spot on-it is an industry with a magnetic attraction to the greedy, the naive and the dishonest.

There has been some examination of the extent to which people who use the futures market as a gambling mechanism are likely to be successful. Perhaps people giving consideration to entering it on that basis need to think again. They need to be vary careful about the way in which they enter the futures market, the basis upon which they enter it, the purposes for which they enter it and the way in which they ultimately operate within it, because it is a very dangerous area for speculative investment. It is fulfilling, as I have said before, an extremely important function in the increasing complexity, refinement and sophistication of our total commodity and financial trading structures and markets. To a large extent, it is of fairly recent origin and has received only relatively recent acceptance. At one time a serious view was taken of a person engaged in effect in the purchase and sale of commodities, including financial securities of various kinds, which he or she did not own and had no guarantee of access to. The role of the futures market in stabilising and in hedging, quite apart from the speculative element, has been increasingly recognised, appreciated and accepted. One of the concerns is, as I have said, in connection with the wide definition of a futures contract. Despite some tightening of the position by the two draft exposures that have been made available since this matter was first considered by the ministerial council, there is still some residual concern.

I referred to the fact that there is a large element of speculation and gambling involved in the futures market. For example, a survey in the United States shows that between 80 and 85 per cent of speculators in the futures market lose their money. The principal function of futures trading is to enable producers, consumers and merchants to protect themselves from price fluctuations-in other words, to hedge. That is an important function, an important role, fulfilled by the futures market. It is one of the more legitimate roles. The gamblers involved in speculation in the futures markets are not doing anything illegal. Gamblers are as free to go into that market as people are free to go into the ordinary stock exchange and speculate there. A significant case can be made out for the important role those people fulfil, even with the speculative character of those operations, in that market as well.

Of course, a futures contract is a legally binding contract to purchase or sell a set amount of a commodity, a security or a currency on a specific date for a specific time. As I have said, the complexity of those arrangements has increased significantly over recent years. In the situation that gave rise to this legislation, one of the problems which the futures trading industry faced was that deregulation of financial markets attracted into the industry its share of cowboys. In the absence of regulatory legislation, virtually anyone could set himself up as a futures trader. Almost unbelievably, in an era of increasingly stringent requirements in retail investment markets generally, a person with little or no experience in the commodity and currency futures markets could set up a company with an issued capital of just $2, rent some premises and hang up a shingle outside the door.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?

—Such a person was then free to attract a large amount of money from any investor willing to hand it over. If the operator was not a member of the Futures Exchange, he was outside its rules and sanctions. That is one deficiency, in the first place. Even the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission admitted that it had difficulty policing such operations because technically many of them fell outside the definition of `prescribed interest'. The Trade Practices Commission had persuaded some of those cowboy operators to tone down their advertising claims and, apart from this small compromise, these doubtful operators were literally a law unto themselves. Reputable futures exchange dealers estimated that at least four companies were operating outside the rules that governed normal futures operations. Some had rented offices in the same building as the Futures Exchange itself, and in the eyes of some investors this lent an air of legitimacy to those operations.

SPEECH.PARA: An honourable member interjected just a while ago, asking: `What is wrong with that?'. If that is the sort of position the Opposition adopts, if that is the sort of position it wants to maintain, defend and protect as it normally does for the crook operators in the community, that is a matter for members of the Opposition to decide upon. The risk when dealing with such operations is that some may be bucket shops-they match one customer's contract against that of another who has taken the opposite position, or simply gamble that the contract will go against the customer. By contrast, under the Futures Exchange rules a broker is required to trade the contract on the Exchange's trading floor. This means that the contract is registered and its performance is guaranteed to the broker by the clearing house. There is no such guarantee with bucket shop trades.

In conclusion, I repeat: This is extremely important legislation to regulate, control and introduce a great deal more sense into futures trading operations in Australia than has existed. I congratulate the Government for introducing the legislation and indicate my support for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very interested in the contribution of the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown). I gauged that the honourable member could not quite make up his mind as to what his attitude to the futures industry was, because in one breath he was talking about $2 companies and crooks and about greed and cowboys, yet on the other hand he was talking about the necessity to proceed with this legislation, which the Opposition supports. He made the point, and it is a valid point, that this is an important industry. I say to the honourable member for Charlton: Let us not denigrate the vast majority of those people who are involved in this industry, which is important for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I approach this legislation without any prior involvement with the futures market either as a purchaser or as a dealer in futures contracts or as a result of any professional experience as a member of this place or as a country solicitor, as I once was. My layman's definition of a futures contract is a commitment to purchase or sell a commodity or financial interest on set terms at a set price at some future date. It is a growing industry in Australia. As has been mentioned, we have this window in terms of a time frame and, if United States experience is any guide, the industry will continue to grow at exponential rates.

The concept of leverage is central to the futures market. A futures contract allows a market operator to purchase an interest to buy or sell on a minimal deposit. There was a very good example in the Melbourne Age in March 1986 which talked about a standard transaction: An investor goes short on gold, that is, he or she takes out a contract in April to sell 100 ounces of gold at, say, $300 per ounce to be delivered in June. Although the value of the gold is $30,000, the trader has to put down a deposit of only $2,000. After that, every $1 fall in the price means $100 profit. This is because the trader has a contract to sell 100 ounces of gold at $300 an ounce. If the price falls, he or she can close out the contract or cancel it out by buying 100 ounces at the new price and take the difference as a direct profit. If before June the price falls to, say, $290, a $10 decline is worth $1,000 and the trader can close out the contract and earn a 50 per cent return on that initial investment of $2,000. Of course, that is a 50 per cent return minus brokerage fees. We can see that there is pretty big money in this game if one can get it right and, as the honourable member for Charlton pointed out, there are many who from time to time get it wrong. All I say to those involved in the industry or who are peripheral to the industry is: `Watch out if you are going to put your money on the line'.

The basic difference between an option and a futures contract is that options do not commit the holder to buy or sell, whereas futures are a solid commitment. With futures there is a requirement that adverse price movements must be covered by further deposits known as margins, which cover unrealised losses. The calling of margins on a daily basis is, in itself, a significant control. I think that is an important point. If those positions are not met, the clearing house has an ability to close those contracts out. If that all sounds terribly complicated, well, it is, which explains why the market is largely dominated by big players such as banks and others and explains why the number of retail speculators is said to account, on some recent figures cited in the Press, for about only 10 per cent of market turnover. Whilst this Bill is put up in part on the basis of protection for orphans and widows, the reality is that the market is very different from that.

The Bill before the House seeks to regulate the industry. It provides for licensing of brokers and advisers and the provision of fidelity funds. It bans certain market practices and generally establishes a regulatory framework. As a starting point, my personal opinion is that passing regulatory measures to establish a framework for the operation of a free market is a perfectly justifiable role for Parliament, subject, of course, to the establishment of a need for such a framework. The Liberal Party has long held that sort of view. In fact, the trade practices legislation in the time of the Menzies Government was, of course, introduced by Sir Garfield Barwick. The Opposition is supporting the legislation because a regulatory framework is called for by the industry and there are arguments for providing a secure framework so that Australia can capture the opportunities that await in this industry for us. The Sydney Futures Exchange, which is the major player in Australia in terms of futures contracts, wants to get on with the job. That is fair enough and we are prepared to support the legislation. There will, however, be a committee established under the Act and I hope that that Committee and the Attorney-General's Department will review the operations of this legislation on a pretty careful basis.

I put today in this debate some of the points which I see as being important to look at as time proceeds, and essentially they place some greater emphasis on self-regulation as opposed to legislative regulation. I am inclined to the view that the line between self-regulation as a means of proceeding to regulate and legislative regulation, which is the nub of this Bill, has been drawn too much in favour of a legislative framework. The second reading speech of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) really, in my view, is virtually silent on that question, although in terms of the need for a framework overall there is, as was referred to by the honourable member for Charlton, a reference to the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. I read the relevant part of the Campbell Committee's report and found little to substantiate the point that the Minister made in his second reading speech. I might also say that my discussions were limited to people in Melbourne and that those discussions did not, in my view, add much to the argument either. The general comment seemed to be that the legislation is mainly aimed at those operators outside the Australian Financial Futures Market, which is the market based in Melbourne, and outside the Sydney Futures Exchange. If that is right, it would be fair to say that the legislation has some fairly classic characteristics. They are, of course, such that it boils down to an attempt to provide an all-embracing framework, which means covering every possibility, and is thus a proposal to cover all of the lowest common denominators in the industry.

In addition to the points made above, my guess is that the industry accepts it partly because it sees it as inevitable. The States tend to be going along with it on the basis that they feel inhibited by a prior agreement to legislate in accordance with decisions of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, and I have a feeling also that this legislative package has ended up with a life of its own. The big players in the market are not too worried because most are already complying with the accounting procedures, fidelity funds, et cetera, and the legislation certainly gives the market some status, stability and enhanced reputation. My first preference is to follow the world trends and have a futures industry which is, as much as possible, self-regulatory so that, for example, membership of either the Melbourne exchange or the Sydney Futures Exchange could be an automatic exemption from the licensing provisions, the provisos to that being, of course, that there be no unreasonable barriers to entry to the exchanges and that the rules of the exchanges should be comprehensive. There is a place for legislation outlawing criminal practices. Those are the sorts of things which the exchanges are not likely to want to have within their jurisdiction and that certainly is one justification for this Bill and the provisions included in it. This approach-one of greater self-regulation-would certainly obviate the problems of double jeopardy and overlapping jurisdictions. It would also provide, in my view, much greater flexibility than the complicated processes provided by the Ministerial Council.

A further reason for putting these points of view now, with a view to some later amendments as experience is gained with the operation of this Bill, is in fact provided for by the Attorney-General in his second reading speech when we are advised that some parts of the Bill will not come into immediate effect because the National Securities and Companies Commission is currently reviewing the whole question of licensing. I understand that the differentiation between advisers and dealers under the Securities Industry Act may go and the concept of representatives is also being looked at, perhaps with a view to abolition.

As much of this legislation is based on the concept of licensing and on the concept of maintaining a legislative approach similar to the securities industry, it seems slightly odd to be proceeding in the face of the likelihood of such changes to the Securities Industry Act, especially as the new licences are not likely to come in under this Bill until the second half of 1986, and the Securities Industries Act abolitions, if they come into effect, may well arrive in 1987. It says little about the Government's ability to bring this legislative package quickly before the House inasmuch as we have had two exposure drafts, but the industry did not have the opportunity to look at the third draft. As one who only a week ago started to look at this matter, it is a complicated situation when one has a Bill that is 136 pages thick, on which there have been comments in two exposure drafts, and then attempts to reconcile the comments on the exposure drafts with what is in fact the third exposure, which is this Bill. There are some complications, and it is inadequate to have but a week to examine the matter.

I raise some general questions-not as somebody with some legal background but from a layman's point of view in looking at this Bill. The first relates to the definition of futures adviser. Apparently in the first exposure draft there was an exclusion from the definition of futures adviser of the categories of solicitors and accountants in public practice as such whose carrying on of that business is solely incidental to the practice of their profession. For reasons I am unaware of, that exclusion-in other words, keeping the barristers, solicitors and accountants out of the operation of this Act-was done away with by the Government in its subsequent exposure draft. It seems to me that the effect of omitting that exclusion from the definition of futures adviser is that participants in the futures industry may be unable to seek legal advice about the contracts which they enter into unless their solicitor has obtained a futures adviser's licence. That to me is quite absurd and I hope the Government will re-examine it.

I also looked at the definition in regard to publishers of certain advices in regard to the futures industry. There have been some celebrated cases in America involving a Mr Glanville, I think it was, who has an investment newsletter. If he gives the word to sell, everybody sells and the market goes into a heap. I can understand that the Government would like to have a broad net to cover people advising in that sort of capacity. I read that definition four, five or more times and it is hard to get a real feeling as to what it is about. All I can say is that, if my comments are not persuasive in leading the Government to look at the matter carefully, I would hope that the Australian Journalists Association will take a pretty close look at it. I am sure that, if anybody can bring pressure to bear on the Government, it is the AJA.

The second point I wish to make relates to futures contracts themselves and the definition which has already been referred to in this debate. The definition contains an exclusion for certain types of currency and interest rate swap contracts. To be excluded, however, such a contract must have a banking corporation or a merchant bank as a party. An earlier version of the definition which was circulated for comment excluded such swap contracts if they were of a kind to which a bank or merchant bank is commonly a party. The definition in the Bill, by requiring that a banking corporation or merchant bank actually be a party to such a contract, catches normal swap contracts between consenting corporate adults. These contracts are a normal part of day to day financial management for many medium to large businesses in Australia. The ability is preserved in paragraph (e) of the definition to prescribe classes of agreements as being excluded from the definition of futures contract, but no indication has been given of the classes of agreement which it is proposed to prescribe. I am sure that the industry will be interested in some reaction to that.

There is, of course, another solution which is much more wide ranging. That would be to exclude from the definition of futures contract all contracts between bodies corporate. This would ensure protection for those individuals who participate in the futures industry, while not hampering the conduct of a normal business transaction. There is ample precedent for such an exclusion-for example, in the credit Acts which have been introduced in a number of States and Territories, and the money-lending legislation which preceded it. I am aware that that is a much broader proposition, but it is well worth looking at if experience with the current legislation is not what is hoped for it.

I turn to clause 13, which gives power to the Commission to require the production of books. Speaking as a layman, that is obviously based on the proposition that if there are problems there must be wide investigative powers to track them down; people can move money from account to account and so on. It is a wide power which can cover the financial position or character of people who have worked for a broker, regardless of whether the books have anything to do with the futures industry. I think it needs to be looked at, and although clause 13 (1) (a) limits the power there should be some inexpensive and quick means of interposing a disinterested third party to assess whether the required production is reasonable. In those circumstances I believe it would be unreasonable to require somebody who has simply worked for a broker to have to go to the Supreme Court to get some protection against an abuse of power.

A further point relates to the fact that a number of clauses suspend the normal rule that people are not required to incriminate themselves. I do not know whether that is a standard rule in legislation of this type, but it is a question which I believe should be answered. I would like to hear what justification there is for it. Lastly, clause 39 (3) allows the Commission to make an innocent party pay for the costs of an investigation, regardless of whether the costs are reasonable. That seems onerous to me and again needs to be looked at. We all know that some Queen's Counsel in this country charge like wounded bulls, and there is no doubt that if one has not lost everything on the futures exchange, one soon could if one had to foot the bill of an investigator appointed by the Government who also happens to be a QC.

There are a number of other matters which I would like to have raised but for time constraints, but the queries and matters I have raised substantiate the argument that more time should have been devoted to examining this legislation in the Parliament. Certainly more notice should have been given to honourable members to examine it and more notice given to members of the industry who will be so greatly affected by it.

I conclude by saying that, although this subject is for most people as dull as dishwater, this is an important industry and we must make sure that the right decisions are taken when implementing the legislative framework. This Bill will need amending in due course, and I hope that my remarks will be useful when that time comes. I also take the opportunity of thanking some people in Melbourne who are involved in the industry, none of whom would claim to be responsible, nor should be so held to be responsible, for any comments I have made. I refer to Dr Goss of Monash University, Mark Lampell of Bache, Cortis and Carr Ltd, Mr John Field of Blake and Riggall, the Law Institute and Mr Heffernan of the Melbourne Stock Exchange, all of whom gave of their time. I appreciate it when people outside this place are prepared to give of their time and make some fruitful and useful comments in regard to this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 160-clause Futures Industry Bill 1986 is the product of a long period of gestation in that it arose out of a formal agreement executed by the Commonwealth and all the States on 22 December 1978, in the halcyon days of the Fraser Government. It has taken some eight years to reach this point of time, and in common with the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) and the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) I question whether the Government has given the Parliament, indeed the members of both Houses, sufficient time to look at this legislation. It is novel legislation. It effectively is a code. It contains 160 clauses. I agree with the honourable member for Flinders that some provisions of this Bill-say this quite bluntly as one of the Queen's counsel to whom he referred but not one of the type who charge like a wounded bull-are almost unintelligible. They are gobbledegook, legal jargon. I do not know what magical little minds have been working away by candlelight at midnight to come up with some of these provisions. Whatever the intention, I am talking of the final product, and the first think I say about this legislation is that it will be an absolute bonanza for the legal profession because there are provisions here which I find almost impossible to understand, let alone comprehend. When the Attorney-General and Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) introduced the second reading of this Bill he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The parties to the formal agreement have agreed that the co-operative scheme should be extended to cover the regulation of the futures industry and franchising. The necessary amendments to the formal agreement have been approved by each participating government and the amending agreement is presently in the process of being signed by each of the parties. In accordance with that amending agreement, the proposed futures legislation has been agreed to unanimously by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. In the coming months, the other parties to the formal agreement will be introducing legislation that will apply the Commonwealth legislation throughout Australia.

Well, Mr Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General, I will have a bet with you. I do not think the legislation will be applied identically in other parts of Australia because I think that some of the things wrong with this Bill will be picked up by people when there is more time to look at it. I accept the overall thrust that, for the reasons which are quite clear, the need to have a uniform regulatory system governing the futures industry in Australia has been recognised. It was recognised by the Campbell Committee and it has been endorsed by the Sydney Futures Exchange. Everybody seems to think that it is very necessary.

It strikes me as slightly Gilbertian that, at a time when both sides of the Parliament are talking about deregulation, we are about to very heavily regulate an industry which is not only exciting but also highly private enterprise oriented and very speculative. As we know, one can make a fortune on the futures exchange, and one can lose very substantially. It is a high risk business. However, it seems that the industry wants to be regulated-heaven knows why-by a 160-section Act of the Commonwealth of Australia to apply in the Australian Capital Territory and then to be unanimously re-enacted in every State of the Commonwealth. Well, I find that somewhat odd. However, the Deputy Prime Minister pointed out in his second reading speech that the Bill will, firstly, require futures brokers and advisers to be licensed. There does not seem to be a great problem with that. Secondly, it will establish a system for the approval of futures exchanges and clearing houses. That seems fairly straightforward. Thirdly, it will require futures exchanges and futures associations to establish a fidelity fund for the protection of clients. No-one could argue with that. Fourthly, it will provide criminal sanctions for manipulative and fraudulent practices, and, finally, it will require futures brokers to maintain adequate records and separate client funds from their own funds. All that is good.

However, nowhere in the Deputy Prime Minister's speech do we have detail about what I will call the nasties in this Bill. I am well aware that our lead speaker in this debate, the honourable member for North Sydney, the shadow Attorney-General, has indicated that the Opposition will not be opposing nor moving any amendments. I will quickly run through a few of the nasties I see so that at least I am on the record in the short time available to me as having drawn the attention of Parliament to some of these things, and then in the concluding minutes available to me I will expose this Government-this Hawke socialist Government which talks with a forked tongue-because I am going to compare what it has done in this Bill with what it did in the Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Bill, as it strikes me all as a little bit strange. We did not hear, for example, the Deputy Prime Minister in his second reading speech talk about the power of the Commission to require production of books, which was referred to by the honourable member for Flinders and also, I think, in passing by the honourable member for North Sydney. I refer to the power of a magistrate, under clause 14, to issue a warrant to seize books. The provisions of clause 15 dealing with offences did not seem to get much of a mention at all in the Attorney-General's second reading speech, and nor did the provisions of clause 16, whereby copies or extracts shall be admitted in evidence. We heard precious little in relation to clause 17, which hacks into the well-established solicitor-client privilege.

The honourable member for North Sydney, very conscious of these matters, and indeed the honourable member for Flinders, have just drawn attention to the fact that-I am sure members of the legal profession will be interested to know this-if they fall within the ambit of the clause 17 provisions, which everyone wants and is unanimous about, they will be liable to a fine of $1,000 or imprisonment for three months, or both. I simply make the point: Surprise, surprise, we did not hear anything about this in the speech of the Deputy Prime Minister. If we run through the remaining provisions, we find that the honourable member for Flinders referred to the question of the right to remain silent, the right not to incriminate oneself-that now goes out the window-disclosure to commission, investigation of certain matters and power of the court to make certain orders. One can go right through the investigation provisions in Division 2. I take on board, as everyone agrees we will not oppose and we will not amend it, that there are some interesting provisions in relation to powers of inspection, seizure of books, the question of privilege, the question of incrimination and the admissibility of evidence. There is even a clause 31 on the weight of evidence which is most extraordinary, but, there you are, it is there. Everyone agrees with it, so who am I, the Federal member for Denison, to utter one word of criticism. Having said that, I invite people in the next few weeks and months to have a look at these provisions to see whether or not they contain matters which might perhaps be looked at in a slightly different light by the various State Governments when they come to introduce mirror legislation in their own areas.

As I have said, the Deputy Prime Minister has said-who am I to doubt-that it is the unanimous decision of everyone that this will be done and that there will be identical legislation passed in every other State of the Commonwealth. I do note, and simply say in passing, that the only legislation in Australia at this moment dealing specifically with the futures industry is the New South Wales Futures Markets Act. Even though that has been brought in by and during the term of the Wran Government, there are a lot of provisions in this legislation which do not appear in the New South Wales legislation. In the remaining moments available to me I will draw the obvious comparison. Why is it, short of complying with the formal agreement, short of giving effect to the agreement executed between the Commonwealth and the States three days before Christmas in 1978-nearly eight years ago-that this Government rushes to legislate to effectively set up a very extensive, detailed investigatory procedure in relation to futures when barely four weeks ago in this Parliament this Government rushed with equivalent speed in directly the opposite direction? It is just four weeks ago that the Trade Practices (Transfer of Market Dominance) Amendment Bill 1986 which I described at that time as corrupt legislation came into this House. What that effectively did was to take away the power under clause 50 with respect to a proposed Trade Practices Commission inquiry in relation to the then attempted takeover or raid on Australia's biggest company, Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. I am not going to re-litigate the issue, but I just want to place on record that, if one wants any vindication of everything I said in my speech on 20 March this year-it can be found from pages 1731 through to 1734 of Hansard-one has only to read the ruling of His Honour Mr Justice Marks in the case of BHP versus National Companies and Securities Commission in the Supreme Court of Victoria, dated 26 March 1986, which is some six days after my speech. I say in conclusion that, when one compares the judgment of His Honour Mr Justice Marks in the BHP case in the Supreme Court of Victoria on 26 March and his remarks about the Bell company and Mr Holmes a Court with my humble remarks in this Parliament on 20 March, one would be staggered to see that either I am quite prescient and a mind reader-which I certainly am not-or that there may have been more than a smidgin of truth in the things I said in the House at that time. The legislation will be passed with bipartisan support. The whole world wants it. I can see great benefit to the legal profession. I think it will be a gold mine. I wish the legislation well. The honourable member for Flinders said that this is as dull as dishwater. I do not think it is as dull as dishwater. I think the honourable member for North Sydney put a bit of sparkle in it. I hope I have gingered-
