DEBATE.TITLE: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 March, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Companies and Securities Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 proposes the following major changes to the companies and securities laws: First, all partial bids are to be restricted to a proportion of each shareholder's holding. The pro rata bid is to be done away with. Second, for both full and partial offers, maximum acceptance conditions are to be prohibited. Third, benefits under escalation agreements entered into within six months of the bid, whether full or partial, are to be cancelled. Fourth, all Part A bids, full or partial, are to be subject to a minimum price, being the highest price paid for shares in the target company by the offeror within the previous four months. Fifth, the so-called multiplier effect is to be eliminated from partial bids. Sixth, shark-repellent provisions may be put in the articles of listed companies which would subject takeover bids to a plebiscite of a target company's shareholders. Seventh, shares held by a nominee or trustee on behalf of different persons are to be deemed to be subject to separate offers for each separate holding. Eighth, the substantial shareholder provisions of the Companies Act are to be amended so that shareholders holding over 10 per cent will be required to notify net variations of only one per cent or more in their holdings.

SPEECH.PARA: Recent events have focused attention on takeovers and takeover law. The most noticeable recent events have been the general high level of takeover activity and the struggle for control of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, which is still, as far as we can judge, going on. An argument has become current which needs only to be stated to be demonstrated to be both groundless and nonsensical. That argument is that to oppose or to propose amendments to legislation affecting takeovers creates market uncertainty. In truth, those protesting about uncertainty are usually players with vested interests in the outcome of the game. Uncertainty is not created by debate over legislation. Whatever market uncertainty may exist at any time results simply from the coincidence of legislative changes being proposed to takeover rules at a time of high levels of takeover activity and particularly at a time when financial reporters, the media in general and sections of the Australian public have become transfixed by the struggle for control of BHP.

The logical consequence of arguing that opposition to amendments creates market uncertainty is either that amendments should never be introduced, which is absurd, or that they should never be opposed, which is equally absurd. Almost invariably, the proponents of this nonsensical argument are direct participants in current market events whose motivation is self-interest in its purest and most uncomplicated form. The other critics frequently come from the camp which would describe itself as informed commentators. Commentators they may be; informed they rarely are.

The lessons from the BHP takeover marathon and the extraordinary sequence of events it has unleashed are these: Look to the legislation; examine its overall effect; do not be diverted by the immediate, by superficially glamorous events, by white knights, black knights or boards and management determined to achieve their purposes and to secure their own position regardless of the interests of shareholders; things settle down; the current becomes the past; the seemingly important becomes the trivial and even the voices of self-interest are heard no more; and, on the subject of self-interest, never forget that those who support or oppose legislation that affects transactions of such huge commercial importance are but rarely motivated by a disinterested desire to set things right. I speak now of the players in the game. Self-interest has many voices. Most frequently, it is disguised as the public good. Yet, if we look to those who promote the public good in such areas as takeover law, when changes may affect their own situations and prospects, it is strange how often the public good mirrors their own private interests.

The Opposition does not oppose this Bill, subject to a concern that it has expressed on the issue of retrospectivity. I communicated to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) a proposed amendment which would have the effect of safeguarding the position of any company which had made a takeover offer by having registered a Part A statement before 3 February of this year or on that day. The reason why 3 February was chosen was that on that day an announcement was made by the Victorian Attorney-General, who is also the Chairman of the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, pointing out that from that day forward anyone who was concerned about takeovers should look to the consequence of making a pro rata bid. He also pointed out, in fairly explicit language, that changes were to be introduced. The Attorney-General has answered and dealt with the request very fairly. He put it to the Ministerial Council and he has advised me:

By a majority decision the Ministerial Council has decided not to support the amendment. In this context, it is relevant to note that the proposed amendment would appear to have no practical effect. I have been informed that there are two current pro rata bids in New South Wales and one current pro rata bid in Victoria. In the case of each of these bids, the Part A statement was lodged after 3 February 1986.

Of course, I accept that statement from the Attorney-General. Since the amendment that was to have been proposed by the Opposition would have no practical effect, the Opposition does not propose to put the amendment which would have overcome a retroactive effect in the Bill.

Turning now to the Bill, there are three general criticisms that may be made of it. We make these criticisms without opposing the Bill. The first is that there has been no attempt to analyse the economic effects of the Bill on takeovers. It should be obvious to anyone interested in economic policy that takeover rules can have a crucial effect not only on the conduct of take overs but also on the level of foreign investment in Australia. I will quote from a paper recently given by Mr John Green, a partner in Dawson Waldron, a major firm of Sydney solicitors, who said:

We have had too limited research into the question and given the possible impact on the economy, it is hardly appropriate to rush in with new legislation. Although this Bill has been very hastily drafted, as is apparent on reading it, most of the principles on which it is based have been considered and debated at some length . . .
But what has been lacking in the whole debate is an overview, particularly an economic one.
For example, the major thrust of this Bill is to ban pro rata partials. But ask yourself how is that consistent with the Federal Government's current foreign investment policies?

On the one hand, the Government is seeking to encourage foreign capital into Australia, subject to a rule-of-thumb limitation on 51% equity. But now a foreign company which wants to acquire control, but no more, of an Australian company can no longer make a bid for just 51%. To get 51%, under a truly proportional bid, the foreigner will have to bid for more because, as we all know, not everyone will accept. Under a pro rata bid there is a greater prospect of success than there will be under a proportional bid. So to limit an acquisition to 51% and get it will not now be possible.
By this Bill, the Government is encouraging foreign companies to make full bids and then subsequently to `Australianise'.
The obvious result is that some foreign investors will be deterred from investing in Australian companies. This is not idle speculation as Mr Green has said in his paper:

The acquisition may become less attractive. If you think the risks of foreign investors turning away from Australia because of this Bill are small, you should ask your lawyers or financial advisers not if, but how many, proposals of which they are aware have walked away.

Secondly, there are deficiencies which appear to exist in the legislation and which appear to be available to be exploited by those who would be interested and concerned in getting around the legislation. I refer to what seems to be thought to be the consequence of the prohibition on pro rata partial bids and the introduction of proportional bids. Mr Green gave an example of a possible way around it and, as I recall, it went somewhat along these lines: Since the limitations on proportional bids-that is, the restriction that one shall not have cash bids on a pro rata basis-apply, of course, only to cash bids, if one throws in as a minor consideration something along with the cash, such as a few cans of beer if one happens to be a takeover company which is in the business of making beer, one may be able to get around the provisions of the Bill. That would certainly not appear to be impossible and it would certainly not appear to be the only problem that exists in terms of loopholing.

The third general criticism is that the Bill rests on a number of doubtful assumptions. Let me take just one. There is a plebiscite provision which is designed to give the ordinary shareholder a say in whether or not his or her company should be taken over. But this provision may instead be used by entrenched minorities to protect their position and to prevent the ordinary shareholder selling at a good price. Let me elaborate upon that. The constituent documents of a company may provide, under the Bill, that shares acquired under a partial take- over bid may not be registered unless a resolution approving the registration has been passed by the shareholders. I point out that that means that one's ability to deal with one's shares is dependent on a vote of one's fellow shareholders. The offeror and person associated with the offeror are prohibited from voting on a plebiscite resolution and the approval required is to be the approval of such proportion, not exceeding one-half, as is specified. The offeror is to be given notice of the result of the resolution before a date 14 days prior to the end of the offer period. Ten per cent of shareholders can ask for a review by a court of the plebiscite provisions.

Let me now go to the problem. Plebiscite provisions are not to continue in force for more than three years after their adoption but may be renewed in the same manner as applies to adoption. A company proposing to introduce or renew a plebiscite provision is required to send a statement to shareholders explaining the effect of the provision and the reasons for it, including factual matters and principles, stating whether any director is aware of a particular takeover proposal and, in the case of renewal, reviewing the advantages and disadvantages of such a course. But the plebiscite provisions could enable existing controlling shareholders to defeat a partial bid which sought to challenge their control. For example, let us assume that the company seeking to acquire a proportion of shares in the target company owns just on 20 per cent. That means that if that organisation wishes to acquire, say, 51 per cent it has to bid for around 40 per cent to 50 per cent of the shares held by all other shareholders. But there will be some who will not want to sell. If one has an entrenched minority-for example, another group owning 20 per cent or 25 per cent-and if remembering that the offeror is excluded from voting the shareholding is dispersed amongst fairly small shareholders, the consequence of general shareholder apathy is that the entrenched minority could prevent a takeover offer from being successful.

As I have said, the changes proposed rest on a number of doubtful assumptions and that is one of them. The financial community is divided upon the benefits, which is understandable because we are dealing with a quite new ball game. We should ask the question: What will be the effect on the level of takeover activity? Some argue that there are too many takeovers but nobody is able to say what should be a proper level of takeover activity. Economists may be able to provide an ideal by definition but to translate that theoretical definition into market reality is impossible. Next, we should understand that there is a very real probability that the level of takeover activity will diminish, not simply because some foreign investors will be deterred, but because under proportional partial rules the cost of acquisition may become higher.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—No prompting.
—In the words of Mr Mark Burrows of Baring Brothers, Halkerston and Partners Ltd:

SPEECH.PARA: One thing is certain, the move to proportionate bidding will if an offer is made increase the price that the partial offeror will have to pay and that will no doubt be a good thing for shareholders. My question is whether or not that higher price, but more particularly the risks transferred from the offeree to the offeror is such that no bid at all emerges.

I heard an interjection earlier from an honourable member on the opposite side of the chamber to the effect that a reduction in takeover activity would be no problem. I would ask the honourable gentleman, although I cannot ask him directly, whether he thinks it is a good idea that management should be entrenched.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said `no prompting'. The honourable member for Denison was helping you to make your speech. You were being prompted from behind. That is what I was referring to.

—I point out to the honourable gentleman that one of the things I am capable of doing is making my own speeches. They may be good, they may be bad or they may be brilliant; but I do not have to be prompted, even though I always welcome interjections from the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), whose eloquence and learning are always matters of great interest to this House.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to some more specific and very mundane questions arising under the legislation. First of all, I will deal with the argument relating to partial bids. As I have said, we do not oppose the Bill but I think we need to understand that some major questions arise out of it. The argument for change from pro rata partial takeover or partial takeover to strictly proportional partial takeovers runs along the following lines: The rationale is to ensure equality of opportunity between shareholders. The present system, so it is argued, lends itself to favouritism towards large or strategic shareholders. The partial bid will include a premium for the value of effective control and, once this is passed, the value of the remaining shares will ordinarily have been reduced. The idea is, therefore, that the opportunity to participate in the value of any controlled premium should be proportionally available in respect of all shares. It is also argued that pro rata partial bids which promote competition between shareholders to maximise their advantages result in a coercion of shareholders and their failure to accept may result in their being locked in, or so it is said. On the other hand, proportional bids, it is argued, by definition provide each shareholder with an equal opportunity to participate in the benefits of the bid. The investment community is divided on this proposal. The effect of the proposed change is not clear. As I have said, the drafting is by no means free of ambiguity or possible loopholes. We lack an in-depth analysis of the operation of the entire takeover system. We lack, in particular, an analysis of the economic effects of the present proposals.

In terms of some specific comments that should be made, I turn to clause 6(d) which will amend section 16(2) of the Act. It states that the cash price specified in the offer must not be less than the highest price per share paid or agreed to be paid under an agreement to purchase shares made in the four-month period prior to the date of dispatch of the offer. One must ask this question: What is the real rationale for that? One can say that it adds to fairness, but it represents a fairly fundamental interference with the market process. Some would argue that it is fair that we should interfere in that way. But we must ask ourselves: Is it really fair? Is it really right?

Let me give an example to the House. Let us assume that one has made an agreement in the four months before one is to make one's take- over offer, that is, before one dispatches one's offer, and one has bought shares at a very high price. Let us assume that the bottom falls out of the oil market and one is purchasing a company such as Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd-although if one could afford to purchase a company such as BHP one probably would not need to worry about too many things. But one is entitled, I think, to commercial certainty. Why is it that, if the target company becomes very much less valuable as a consequence of matters which one did not know about at the time one made one's pre-bid acquisitions, one should be forced by the law to bid only at a price which, on what is then known of the market, does not reflect the true worth of the target company?

Let me raise another matter, of a very technical nature. A bidder or his associate will be prohibited from giving or receiving benefits under agreements entered into within six months of a takeover offer. The proposed amendment provides that any agreement, arrangement or understanding, which is defined widely to include informal, oral and equitable agreements, made in the six months prior to a takeover offer or a proposal for a takeover offer whereby an offeror or person associated with an offeror gives to or receives a benefit from a person who acquires shares in the company, is void. This is to be done by clause 10, adding a new section 39b. If the main object of this amendment is to prevent agreements which will circumvent the plebiscite provisions, its fate should be decided in accordance with the fate of the plebiscite provisions. As I have pointed out, the plebiscite provisions in themselves raise some fairly fundamental questions for the House.

The Opposition does not oppose the Bill. However, we draw attention to problems that appear either to arise under the Bill, to be inherent in it, or to be possibilities that need to be considered. I hope that the Government and, in particular, the Attorney-General will take the criticisms that have been made of the Bill in the spirit in which they have been offered and will look very carefully to any problems that may emerge under the legislation. I particular, I ask the Attorney-General to take note of two things: First, the economic effects of the proposals and secondly, and in particular, the likely economic effects of the proposals on the level of foreign takeover activity. As a country we have gone past the stage of being frightened of foreigners. We certainly should have gone past that stage. We should understand that foreign investment in this country is needed. We should not wish to divert it. I fear that a consequence of this Bill may be that foreign investment will be diverted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Companies and Securities Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 I draw on some comments made earlier this evening by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) in the context of his expressing some concern about the State agreements and the operation of the Ministerial Council. For better or for worse we have a Commonwealth, a Federation and a Constitution which delineate powers. Honourable members opposite referred to the riches to be secured by the legal profession. The honourable member for Denison was somewhat saddened, feeling that at his age and with his capacities he perhaps would be better occupied with the aftermath of this legislation. That is not caused by this legislation. It is not caused by this Government. I suggest that it is much more a result and always will be a result of a model of Federation and a Constitution that divide powers. A recent newspaper article by Leigh Masel, which reports comments by a previous chairman of the National Companies and Securities Commission, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Despite some obvious flaws concerning the political administrative model associated with an agency which is so largely bent upon maintaining a spirit of co-operation by seven government bureaucracies . . . the Formal Agreement reflects in a general way the broad objectives of a mixed economy . . .

The fact is that, given the constitutional and legal responsibilities we have, the model works reasonably well. In effect the Commonwealth and the six States have agreed that these changes are appropriate following a fair degree of public debate and discussion hence the dating and including of offers that are currently in train. The arguments about proportional and pro rata takeovers have been difficult in recent times. They raise issues of equity, fairness and justice. The fact that these issues are being addressed and are affecting current takeovers is more than appropriate.

I sat and listened with interest to the arguments of the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) about entrenched minorities and the apathy of shareholders. I find it difficult to understand, in terms of my mathematical understanding, how a takeover bid-up could not handle an entrenched minority. It is purely a question of the proportion of shares one wants to take over. Unless the minority is 48 or 49 per cent, I would have thought it was a question of the degree of takeover and the degree of offer. To suggest that the legislation is faulty because shareholders are apathetic may relate more to the size of the bid being made than to the legislation itself. Of course the honourable member made no mention of the locked in minorities which, in so many cases, have been the victims in Australian takeover and share dealings where a small number of shareholders become, as it were, victims of the system. I am sure that we all know of small shareholders who have owned shares in companies which have been taken over and perhaps become unlisted. Their shares can then be sold only to the then majority owner at a very difficult to establish price.

The other aspects covered by the Bill regarding pre-bid selling, the multiplier effect and small shareholders protections are all important. It is probably appropriate to comment on what I see our system is supposed to have been doing. Our system provides the capacity for Australians from all walks of life and from all backgrounds to invest in, have partial ownership of and involvement in an Australian company whereby they feel that they are part of what is happening in the country. They feel that their money is doing some good and they have an active involvement in the affairs of the nation. Those people who, once upon a time, were perhaps the bulk of the shareholders-certainly in some companies they are still the majority of shareholders-have become less visible and less significant as we have seen major organisations, which are capable of marshalling very large amounts of money, launching bids on companies to which the small shareholder has no chance of responding. I suspect that very few of the shares of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd that were transferred in recent weeks were sold to small shareholders. The sellers and the buyers were not small Australians or normal Australian shareholders. They were the large Australian shareholders and institutions, many of whom were protected under various other financial arrangements.

The aspect that Mr Masel raised in his comments in the Australian Financial Review today goes perhaps a bit deeper and reflects the concern shared by members of the Opposition. It is interesting to note that both the Opposition speakers are from the legal fraternity. The comments Mr Masel made concerned the ultimate determinant. It is of some merit to read his comments into the record of this debate because I am sure that his words will be appropriate and relevant for quite some time to come. He stated:

Basically the legislation administered by the commission should provide a framework for business activities such as takeover bids and more particularly provide a scheme whereby shareholders are furnished with information to enable them to make up their own minds on the facts. They should be able to see (with competent advisers if need be) the problems that may arise and to make their own individual decisions on the offer documents.
Who then should be the appropriate forum for the determination of these matters-the commission or the courts?
He goes on to state:

When one considers the history of regulatory commissions and the reasons which prompted them, we in Australia seem to be too ready to turn accepted doctrine on its head by allowing the debate to occur, not in the market place or within their forum designed to balance competing interests such as a regulatory commission, but in the courts. This must have the effect of bringing about regulation which will prove not only cumbersome and ineffective, but also one developed within a labyrinth in which only security lawyers can find their way.

I think Mr Masel expresses the concern of many people, the concern that to be a shareholder these days one almost needs to be a corporate lawyer. If one has some form of shareholding one almost needs a Queen's Counsel on one's payroll and a permanent presence in the Exchange and virtually needs to be a fully professional share dealer or share purchaser. That underlines very strongly the need for not just the amendments we are debating today but the overall existence of the Commission itself. In the same newspaper today we get a quite different view in the Chanticleer column, which states:

One government setting the regulations or even better a less black letter approach would solve the problem of the present system where a group of politicians set decisions, of which none are ultimately responsible, and then there are the delays of some months before the decisions are actually made law.
The loser in this stupidity is the market . . .

The point between those two comments in the one newspaper is that on the one hand the ex-chairman of the Commission is saying that the Commission and the regulatory bodies should be the appropriate forum to settle, rule and arbitrate on these matters and on the other hand the so-called Chanticleer is saying that the courts make a mess of it, so technically we should not have any legislation covering this matter. That would mean that those who could best handle share dealings can do so. In the first view the concern is clearly for normal individual shareholders; in the second view the concern is clearly for the market. The market does not consist of normal Australian shareholders; the market consists of market specialists who are mobilising very large amounts of capital or borrowings and transferring shares in very high volumes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purposes of the Companies and Securities Legislation Amendment Bill were outlined by the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). Firstly, partial takeover bids are to be restricted to proportional bids, that is, partial takeover offers must be made for a specified proportion of each shareholder's shareholding. Secondly, the cash price specified in the offer must be not less than the highest price per share paid, or agreed to be paid, under an agreement to purchase shares made in the four-month period prior to the date of dispatch of the offers. Thirdly, the maximum acceptance provisions will be prohibited. Fourthly, with retrospective operation of the legislation, if offers under a pro rata partial bid remain open when Part 2 of the Bill comes into operation, currently at the date of royal assent, they will be deemed to be for a proportion of each shareholder's shareholding. Fifthly, where an acquisition of shares is made in a listed public company through an agreement made in the four months preceeding the date of an on-market takeover announcement, the price to be specified in a subsequent announcement of offer is deemed to be that originally agreed to regardless of any variation in accordance with the terms of the agreement. Sixthly, acceptance of proportional takeover offers is restricted to persons who are registered or are entitled to be registered as the holders of the shares to which the offer relates but who have not acquired their shares from a shareholder who has previously accepted the offer in relation to the prescribed proportion of his shares. Seventhly, where shares are held by a nominee or trustee on behalf of different persons, a takeover offer is deemed to be a separate offer to each beneficial shareholder. Eighthly, constituent documents of a company may provide that shares provided under a partial takeover bid may not be registered unless a resolution of approval has been passed by the shareholders. Ninethly, a bidder or his or her associate will be prohibited from giving or receiving benefits under agreements entered into within six months of a takeover offer. Tenthly, substantial shareholders will be required only to notify net variations of one per cent of their entitlement where such variation does not result in their being entitled to less than 10 per cent of the company's voting shares.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank honourable members for the calm and dispassionate way in which they have dealt with the Companies and Securities Legislation Amendment Bill 1986! I am delighted to know that the Bill is not opposed. I can understand the concern of honourable members because companies and securities legislation is a matter for concern. The honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) talked eloquently about the difficulties in the trade practices area which to some extent come into the area of companies and securities legislation. Mergers and monopolies are under the control of the trade practices legislation. But when one turns to market forces and takeover provisions, of course, one is then dealing with the Securities Industry Act which would perhaps relate to mergers or transfers of monopolies.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue, of course, is the legislation itself. It has not been opposed and I can understand why that is so. Honourable members who have taken part in the debate this evening have all expressed concern, as has the ministerial council. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) was somewhat critical of what he regarded as the delay in the matter. I am not too clear about the basis of the 5 1/2-year period to which he referred. But let me make the point-

TALK.START.PARA: —From 22 December 1978.

—That is a lot longer than 5 1/2 years ago. I wonder where the honourable member obtained that figure. But let me come to the point and try to deal with it fairly. The ministerial council received the report from the Law Review Committee in August 1985. So there has been no delay from the point of view of what this Bill is about. It is concerned-and I still think it has difficulties in delivering what it is concerned about-to guarantee that the small shareholder gets the same chance and the same price as the large shareholder. This has not happened, as honourable members can see. It has not happened because of the issues concerning what is called the pro rata situation. Big investors and shareholders could wait until the last moment and then take all the shares on offer. The small shareholder-if honourable members want to talk about the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, there are 186,000 of them-would not be given one offer.

SPEECH.PARA: The idea was to put some equity into the situation and develop a scheme so that everybody would get the offer. That has not happened, either, despite the fact that this piece of legislation has come into being. The ministerial council is still concerned about the efforts being made to get around the provisions. I am concerned-and one must look at the matter from the point of view of the ministerial council-to see whether we have achieved the correct result. We have got nowhere near it. Let us look at what has happened recently. The small shareholder who might have wanted to take the $7.70 offer did not get into the ring at all because legislation was interpreted by the court to the effect that it was not a fair offer. I make no judgment about that. But in the process of making the assessment of whether it was a fair offer or otherwise, another person came in and took 20 per cent of the shares without any worries at all. There seems to be some cross-fertilisation between the existing group in BHP and the new buyer because they took 20 per cent of each other's holdings. From the point of view of exposure--

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but on the market.
—On the market, but of course the terms are still not able to be disclosed. The honourable member should look at it this way: How were the financial arrangements made?
—On the market--

—The honourable member is not listening; he should listen for a moment. I make the point that in the process 20 per cent of the shares are gone. All the little people are still on the sideline. There is an inquiry by the National Companies and Securities Commission regarding the process of the financial arrangements-who was lending money to whom, perhaps in order to buy back the shares. That has now been the subject of a High Court challenge which will insist, perhaps, that that information should still be kept secret.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Denison has been so anxious to pillory Holmes a Court-I have no brief for any of them-by saying what a dreadful thing he did. We now find that his offer is now available to the small shareholder after all this time. In the process, because of this endeavour to give everybody fair and equitable opportunities, somebody else has gone into the market, taken a very dominant position and acquired a 20 per cent holding-it appears that there is a cross-holding involved-and the financial arrangements are still not known. I make that point.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the market has gone over that price.
—It might have been a higher price. But what was the concern to stop the small shareholder taking the $7.70 offered in the first bid?
—He can get a better price now.

—He could not at the time. The point that honourable members opposite are overlooking is that 20 of the top shareholders in BHP own about 40 per cent of the shares. If one looks at the investment procedures on the share market, one will find that those who are interested in superannuation funds must get quick profits, within about three months. So they buy and sell BHP shares perhaps three times a year.
—There is nothing wrong with that.
—There is nothing wrong with it at all, except the small shareholder cannot get into the act because of all the restrictions-
—Of course he can. The small shareholder can get a better price now.

—If the honourable member for Ryan would only look at the matter from this point of view: The small shareholder has not been able to get off the ground until now. Honourable members opposite have been very anxious to say what was wrong with this offer to the small shareholder. Now the small shareholder is able to take it after all this time. In the process, of course, there has been an arrangement with a very friendly board. The companies have 20 per cent of each other's holdings and there have been drinks in the board room to say what a great result it is. One wonders how the 186,000 small shareholders can get into the act. If everybody is so concerned about the small shareholder being able to get the same offer-
—You do not know what you are talking about.
—I happen to know what I am talking about because the honourable member is very anxious to stop me saying it. In fact, he voted against it.
—No, I am all for the market. Give everybody a chance on the market.
—But the honourable member did not let them get into the market. The honourable member is trying to stop me talking. The issue at the moment-
—I ask the honourable member for Ryan to cease interjecting.

—I think he ought to. We are trying to say, at a ministerial council level, that there is a better mechanism of making provision for the small shareholder. It can easily be done by the National Companies and Securities Commission acting as trustee for the bid. It would be very easy. We should get rid of all of this nonsense that there should be some debate as to the merits of the Part A statement. Honourable members opposite did not see the small shareholder debating the merits of the Part A statement. They did not see the small shareholder having a chance to deal with the movement of 20 per cent of the shares. They did not see any of that. This evening we are debating legislation on the basis that something ought to be done about it. I agree with that point; let us agree on that issue. But let us not have too much regulation and litigation on the basis that the small shareholder is being deprived of an offer when in fact he could not even take it. The people who did take the offer and have moved the shares have been the big investors, and that is the risk of the market.

SPEECH.PARA: It is about time that we looked at the matter from the point of view of the ministerial council to see whether we can free this up completely. If there is to be a takeover offer and the offer is made, it should be guaranteed that the funds are deposited in such a way, particularly through the Commission, that the small shareholder gets his share immediately. We should get rid of all of this nonsense regarding litigation to prevent these situations. As honourable members know, the offer that was originally prevented from coming into operation is now in operation after all this time. Yet there has been a massive movement in the change of shares, a massive movement regarding the control of that company. The national interest had to be preserved from the point of view of the steel industry which the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) and others are concerned about. We were not concerned with the share market as such, but the fall out to the nation if the steel industry were to be closed down. So we do have an interest in the matter. When one discusses the share market, one must make this point: If the cash management trusts and the superannuation funds are to make a profit-and there is nothing wrong with that-there will be a continual mass movement in shares. It will happen frequently. The small shareholder may never get into the issue because the big transfers involve blocks of shares. That is the problem. If one is talking about takeover offers-I am referring to the equity situation-and one wants to guarantee that that can happen, the small shareholder should be given a chance to be able to take up that bid. At the moment it is not likely to happen because there is far too much litigation.

The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) was also worried about what one would call an entrenched minority. He is right about that. One matter to which he might address his mind, though, in terms of making the plebiscite provisions into the constituent documents, is that there must be a special resolution, and that would require approval of 75 per cent of the members.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of the members who voted.

—Yes, 75 per cent. That is seen to be a bit of a safeguard. We have had a long argument about the economic advantages of, and other matters relating to, takeovers. That is an argument that will continue because, as honourable members know, the Industries Assistance Commission suggests, on an economic basis, that there are advantages-that can be a matter of contest-in mergers. In other words, the suggestion is that mergers can produce better productivity and cheaper economy of scale. Does it not follow that that can lead to a conflict in that the Trade Practices Commission may also consider that a merger means a dominance in the market or a lessening of competition? We could have a conflict between the economist and what could be called the legal approach to the issue of the consumer. In the middle, we have the issue of whether, if there are too many restrictions of that sort, the share market would not move very much. We are very anxious to see that the share market is freed up on the basis that we want Australians to be involved in investment in their country. That is the best thing that can happen. But it will not happen readily if there is too much litigation on this issue. What I have been anxious to say to the business community in Australia is that I see nothing wrong with one piece of national companies and securities legislation.
—But you are a centralist.

—It is not a matter of being a centralist. If the business community does not want it, it does not happen. We will end up with a plethora of commissions, trying to bring in all sorts of amendments to legislation to guarantee that something will happen for the small investor. I think the small investor in the end is quite happy to take the risk in the same way as the large investor. But too much litigation, too much regulation and too much investigation will have a negative influence on that market.
—That's quite right.

—I know what the honourable member is saying. He agrees with me. If we are to free up this market-and the market is about buying and selling-we ought to be able to let it operate. I think that the business community will agree with me that it would be much better to have one piece of legislation that would free up the market. Everybody would know where they stand. We could readily put it into operation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not critical of my ministerial colleagues in the States, but I assure honourable members that they would be very puzzled if the business community suddenly told them that they did not want all the State corporate affairs commissions. They could certainly continue from the point of view of incorporation of corporations. They could control that aspect and the States would get appropriate revenue from that. But from the point of view of administration, with only one market and only one economy in Australia, I do not know for the life of me why we cannot agree to have one piece of legislation. That would get rid of all the difficulties we seem to be bogged down in, worrying about how we can draft more laws. As the honourable member for North Sydney said, there are always ways of getting around the laws.

I will just finish on this note: The recent example of BHP clearly shows that the small shareholder did not get into the ring at any stage. That is the point. The problem that we now face in this country is how to attract people into the share market. They will not go into the share market if they can never be one of the players, even if they are small shareholders. They will not go into the share market if they can never get an offer for their shares while the big fellow up the road is able to buy in, get what he likes and certainly get a seat on the board. The share market itself ought to realise that there can be excessive regulation. It understands that. It is also important to give information to shareholders.

From the Government's point of view it is important for the development of this country that, in industries such as the steel industry, we have boards of directors who are interested in the industry and do not get involved in the share market purely from the point of view of capital gain. That would not readily be their major interest if their only interest is in a three-to six-month cycle. To be a fair dinkum director of BHP and interested in the steel industry one should put one's heart and soul into deciding what to do about possible competition, whether from Korea or elsewhere, what to do about new technology and how to be an expert in the steel industry. The speculators and financiers can be left there because they can get the profits but, if one gets too caught up in the issue of what is the right price for the shares and consequently loses the industry, there will be nothing to sell in the finish. That was the danger when we moved to introduce the steel industry plan to bolster up the board of BHP, no matter what its composition, to make certain that there was a market in Australia. The company is guaranteed 80 per cent of that market and a bounty also. That is not a bad result for a board. But it will be counter-productive if, in the process of deciding who will own BHP, the board does not become involved in the steel industry. That is the risk. If the managers of the superannuation funds or the life insurance people are interested only in making a turnover, that is simply recycling money. It does nothing for the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is Holmes a Court interested in?

—That is the point. It is a challenge to find out what they are all interested in. In fairness to the existing board, which has spent a fair bit of time in the steel industry, it is very keen about the industry now. But until 1983, if we look at the inquiry in New South Wales, that particular board was prone to get out of the steel industry because there was more profit in oil. The situation has changed and now the board can see the advantages for the company of investing in new technology, doing business with China, developing trade for Australia and at the same time guaranteeing employment, vitality and viability for cities such as Wollongong, Newcastle, Whyalla-and Kwinana, if it were to be opened up. We can see the great advantages for this country. We need to have boards of directors who are not interested only in the quick turnover on the money market. They have to be dedicated to the industry.
—Where does Holmes a Court fit into this?

—He fits the rules that apply at present. His ability to be successful in business is a bit like the ability of the honourable member for Ryan to win a seat-he is able to win a seat without any special criteria except the support of the public; that is his privilege. The rules in the share market are that, if one has enough shares and enough money, one can control a corporation. The honourable member will not disagree with that. My point is that many Opposition members have taken part in this debate but not one of them has disclosed whether he has any shares in BHP. It is an interesting aspect.
—Look; I declare an interest. I have, through a company, 71 shares, I think.
—So you have a pecuniary interest, John?
—An immense one!

—I am wondering why all Opposition members took the considered view that the offer from Holmes a Court was such a terrible thing, yet nobody said a word about the offer from Elders. There was not one word from them about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest the Attorney-General not respond to the interjections.

—I am not responding. I am trying to tell them that I did not hear one word from them against the takeover by Elders. What is the difference between Holmes a Court and John Elliott? It must be politics, for sure. On that note, I thought it appropriate at this stage, and given the lateness of the hour, to have a bit of a workout of what might happen in this market. But the issue is very clear. The Ministerial Council is concerned to guarantee that we do something better than what has happened. It is appropriate to say that the legislation will still need further review. It will need further amendment. It will need freeing up. I would like to see the Ministerial Council agree with that. That will not be an easy task because the question is how best to do it. It is very simple to do it my way. If the amount in a takeover offer, whatever it is, were deposited with the National Companies and Securities Commission as a trustee, the Commission could administer the actual transfer of the shares.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented and seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable member may proceed.
—The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) quite incorrectly accused me--
—How many Elders shares have you got?
—I do not own a share in anything-not even the Soviet Embassy.
—On what point does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

—The Deputy Prime Minister has just asserted that I and others did not speak about small shareholders. I want to refute that statement. I can do so very briefly. It is a gross misrepresentation of what I said. I will just read the precise words which are brief and which will clear the record and show that the Deputy Prime Minister has misrepresented me. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Why has the Hawke socialist Government failed to obtain positive, iron-clad commitments from Mr Holmes a Court . . . that there will be fair dealing and even-handed treatment between all the shareholders of BHP, both corporate and individual, the little people of Australia who have invested in BHP, and that under no circumstances-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member has made his point.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I must finish. I continued:

SPEECH.PARA: under no circumstances will one group of shareholders get a benefit over and above that available to other groups of shareholders?
I stood up for the little people, the small shareholders. This Government betrayed them.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 April, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 concurrently with the Excise Tariff Amendments Bill 1986 and the Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —After the previous address or two in which I found the inconsistencies quite alarming, I am sure that this scintillating discussion on customs and excise will draw the House's attention to fever point. There are those who are regular participants in debates in the customs and excise area but I do not see many in the House. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) is a consistent participant. No doubt, the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) is an excise contributor.
—I am the only teetotaller in this place.
—Order! The honourable member for Melbourne will either sit down in his proper seat or leave the chamber.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for protecting me from such outrageous left wing tactics. I indicate to the House tonight that the Opposition will not oppose the legislation before the House but I will be moving in Committee to oppose clauses 25, 26, and 27, which relate to the maturation of brandy, whisky and rum. The Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) will no doubt swat up and find out what that means. While he is catching his car, I will go on with other aspects of the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the three Bills which are being debated cognately tonight is the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill, which covers a wide ranging series of amendments. Those who have participated in these debates before will recognise that this legislation catches up at the end of a session with a series of amendments that have been brought in from time to time to bring to the notice of the public events that have occurred. The Bill covers amendments to the Coal Excise Act which relate to the method of calculating the excise duty on coal. We, in opposition, have always thought that the proposition that a tax be placed on exports is rather quaint. In government we would move to do something about this. This tax was placed on the export of coal at a stage when the coal industry in Australia, in Queensland in particular, was highly profitable. This tax was brought in as a way of earning revenue for the Government. At a time when the industry is experiencing many difficulties, I very much question the wisdom of its maintenance in this regard. This is purely a measurement of how excise is calculated. It is not objected to by the Queensland Coal Association and I see no reason why we should object to it.

This Bill proposes to amend the Customs Act 1901. Everybody in this chamber, including the Minister, will recall that that is one of the oldest Acts of the Parliament. It has enormous powers, probably more intrusive powers than any other Act on the statute book in Australia. Those who have an intimate knowledge of the Customs area and a great feeling for it will know the enormous powers that rest there. These amendments relate purely to protecting cultural objects and are really a way in which Customs officers can give effect to a notification by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment relating to particular artifacts. Frequently it is not easy for Customs officials to be able to identify the sorts of artifacts or articles which are subject to prohibition in relation to their entry or export because of the definition within the Act. I am hopeful that these amendments will do something to make their task easier. The attempts made to take a variety of items out of Australia have been very wide at times and I am quite sure that these provisions will be of some use.

The re-importation concession is valuable and certainly of interest to the Australian manufacturing sector. The areas which relate to entry of ship's stores and aircraft's stores are, in my view, sensible and I am sure would not have been brought forward otherwise. I think the powers to detain and search persons are appropriate these days given the fact that increasing numbers of people are being subjected to body searches because of drug-related activities. I am aware of many instances of people entering Australia objecting to being searched by certain people. This amendment clarifies that situation.

The most important part of the legislation-the part which we will be opposing in the Committee stage-is the amendment to the Spirits Act 1906. The Government is proposing to abolish the two-year minimum maturation period for brandy, whisky and rum. This removal will be applied from 1 April 1990. I am quite sure that that date will be well known to some honourable members. It should be borne in mind that the producers of brandy who want to see the requisite quality brought into it have an interest in maintaining the two-year maturation period. This proposal is supported by the majority of the members of the Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association. The people who are opposed to this proposal or who propose something less than this are really supporters of a new technology or a requirement for cheaper brandy and they are egged on really by the fact that it is very hard to identify the maturation period of the brandy imported into Australia at present.

Leaving aside the brandy problems, I shall refer to the problems associated with rum. The honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) is well known for his great interest in this matter. I submit to the House that it would not be in the best interests of the rum industry to require it to lower its maturation period. That view has been expressed by those who produce within the industry. The sugar industry is going through a difficult period and I do not think the lowering of standards will help that industry at all. Also, in my view, it does not help the consumer of the product. The consumer benefits substantially from the two-year maturation period, as the Minister would know. That is the subject of a learned dissertation and it is something which I am sure the Minister will follow through. People who operate in this area have raised a number of objections with myself and an honourable senator about the whole process of lowering the period of maturation from two years to six months. If that were done producers fear that they would not be able to give appropriate attention to quality and marketing in their areas.

One of the most serious problems is in regard to labelling. If producers were to label their products so that people would clearly know that a two-year or two-year plus maturated product would sell at a premium as opposed to products maturated for a six-month or thereabouts period which may be cheaper, people would more readily accept the change. However, there is no indication in this legislation or anywhere else that the change will be notified to the consumer. The fact that these changes will not occur until 30 June 1990 indicates to me that the Government recognises that there are some problems within the industry which will take years to work through.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you had a look at section 9 of the Spirits Act?
—Yes, I have, but that does not do anything about the labelling problems, which are the main problems.
—I think it does.

—Does it? The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill makes a number of previously notified changes to the Excise Tariff Amendment Act and inserts new definitions into the Act of what is a brandy, a fruit brandy, a liqueur, a rum, a spiritous beverage and a whisky and restricts the tariff items dealing with these products. It also increases the excise duty on manufactured tobacco, which is a Budget measure. The legislation increases the excise duty on liquefied petroleum gas, which is in line with the Government policy of six-monthly reviews. It is worthwhile saying at this point that the Government's policy of having six-monthly increases in excise in line with the consumer price index is a very sneaky way of charging Australian consumers more. It is a way the Government has been able to increase Government revenue with no one knowing it is doing so. The price of booze goes up, so the Government says: `Let us slip it into the fuel price structure at the same time'. So the people who live on the Darling Downs who have to pay these exorbitant fuel charges and taxes-people who have made a major contribution to the development of this nation, as the previous honourable member for Darling Downs and present honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) would recognise-are locked into a six-monthly upward review of government charges in regard to the most used product on the farm which is fuel.
—You aren't in favour of that, surely!
—Order! The honourable member for Groom will remain silent and will move to his own seat if he wishes to make comments.

—That is not the way to seat such a sterling member as the honourable member for Groom. The other item in this area relates to vice-regal concessions. Until now excise concessions were granted to the occupants of Government Houses. Amendments in the legislation provide that items imported for personal use as distinct from official use will be withdrawn and that only those items used in official duties will be conceded on future occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986 relates to the transfer of powers from the Minister to the Comptroller-General of Customs which has been taking place over some time. In the principal Act, which I think was passed by Parliament about a year ago, some 75 per cent of the powers vested in the Minister were transferred to the Comptroller-General. Provisions in this Bill reduce those powers even further and vests in the Minister only those powers which relate to policy items, rather than administrative items.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very sound!

—It might be very sound but I ask of the Minister concerned that, when proposing this continued dilution of minis- terial responsibility-because power equals responsibility- he consider what has been the experience of the Australian Customs Service since the powers have been administered directly by the Comptroller-General, rather than by the Minister. Have the delegations of power, which were the previous practice, been eliminated? In what way does the Minister these days oversee the activities within the Department in a real administrative sense, bearing in mind-
—As you did when you were Minister.
—A lot more than teddy bears have gone through.
—Tell us about your television set.
—We will talk about teddy bears first.
—I ask honourable members on my right to cease interjecting. I also ask the honourable member for Ryan to ignore the interjections.
—I am sometimes provoked by honourable members, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—You will have the protection of the Chair, if you seek it.

—Thank you very much indeed, sir. I appreciate that very much. I ask the Minister, when he responds to these matters, to address the question of the efficiency of the Customs Service since the transfer of powers from the Minister to the Comptroller-General. Has the Service been improved? Has the experience of not having to effect the delegations that were previously required been beneficial to the Service? Has it been beneficial to the overall supervision of the Customs Service? Has the transfer of powers been beneficial to the management structure of Customs? It is a very significant change and an area in which Parliament should be reported to.

SPEECH.PARA: For many years the Customs Service has been used in one way or another to provide increased protection for the manufacturing sector. If one could not get an Industries Assistance Commission report to stand up in the way one wanted it to, one always tried a dumping charge. If one could get the dumping charge to sit, that in itself was a great way to effect a protective measure. If that failed or the classifications were challenged and failed one always had the right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I have long wondered about the efficiency of this process. The honourable member for Groom frequently appealed about the use of these measures in relation to harvesting machines. I ask the Minister to indicate where the new process has had any impact on this area and whether the powers, having been transferred from the Minister to the Comptroller-General, have allowed the administration to pick up the judgment as to whether certain items ought to be protected. These powers within the Service are very real as is their impact on industries throughout Australia, the manufacturing industry, primary industry and the mining sector.

Customs and excise legislation seldom evokes an enormous amount of interest, although I have noticed that the last few customs and excise debates we have had have attracted more speakers. The importance of the Customs Service is probably becoming more recognised. The role the Service plays in the surveillance of the Australian shore in terms of the entry of prohibited goods such as drugs is increasingly on the minds of Australians. I hope that because of that the Government is giving mind to the Service as a whole. For many years it was always my impression that Customs was allowed to wither on the vine a bit. We did not give the resources it needed to carry out the services Australian citizens wanted. It has only been in recent times when the question of the entry of drugs and immigrants into Australia and the defence of Australian shores has come to the fore, we have seen a recognition of the Service. I am quite sure that the Comptroller-General would be aware of the increasing demands on the Service and hope that his requests to meet those demands will be helped by Government decisions in relation to resources and Government votes. For many years aeroplane and boat services and personnel were inadequate to meet the Customs standards I feel the Australian public would require if it had to put up a defence of its front line operations. I hope that the Minister will respond to these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The shadow Minister for northern development and local government, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), just made a number of observations in relation to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill and the Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill but he missed several main aspects. Therefore, I believe that it is my obligation to talk about some of those aspects. I was a bit surprised that he missed what I would consider to be two very key issues which I would have thought are of great importance to the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: The first issue that I want to talk about is the introduction of new tariff concessions that permit the duty free entry of goods which are reimported after they have been repaired and renovated outside Australia where it is established that such work could not be performed in Australia. This is important because if we are to develop our manufacturing and engineering industries we have to have a process which is very flexible about the repairing and renovation of goods, especially capital goods, that are important in the manufacturing process. In cases where repairs have to be done overseas it would be possible for the goods to be taken out of Australia after the original duty has been paid on them, be repaired and be brought back without new charges being imposed. That kind of flexibility will be important. The Comptroller- General of Customs will be authorised to make a commercial tariff concession order which will permit duty free entry of goods only if it is established that the repair or renovation could not be performed in Australia in the normal course of business. The Comptroller-General has the power to refuse to make an order if this is likely to substantially adversely affect the market for goods or services in Australia or would not be in the national interest. This measure would be very beneficial to Australia because it would give local repairers an opportunity to demonstrate and, if need be, to upgrade their capacity. If an application for the concession is made it will have to be documented and a notice placed in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette giving local repairers the chance of offering their services in the first instance. That is an important feature of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill.

Another important feature of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill is the reference to cultural objects. Again this matter was not referred to by the shadow Minister. This measure will allow Customs officers to seize protected cultural objects notified by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment while the items are under the control of the Australian Customs Service. This amendment is very commendable because its aim is to ensure that items of national cultural significance are not imported or exported for profit or private holding but are held in public trust for the benefit of the whole community to which those objects rightfully belong. The amendment would also extend certain forms of protection to the cultural heritage of other nations in line with the 1970 United States Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation convention on the means of prohibiting and preventing the illicit import or export of cultural property.

This is a very important matter, as honourable members will be aware, for certain nations, especially Italy and Greece, where there has been substantial theft of important cultural items and smuggling of those items into other nations including Australia without much penalty or redress by the original nation concerned. Thus I welcome that clause. It is an important provision and will prevent the situation that has led to the scattering of cultural artefacts and important objects of many nations and people; this has taken place by private individuals and organisations purchasing or otherwise acquiring such items and taking them out of the country of origin without permission. There is currently widespread recognition of the right of people to have such items remain in the nation of origin in the context of its history. I suggest that that recognition should extend also to our nation. Currently debate has arisen about some cultural objects of Aboriginal heritage that have found their way into the Vatican. Maybe that situation could have been prevented had this sort of legislation been in place at the time.

The most surprising thing about the shadow Minister's comments was his failure to refer to an important clause in the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill. I am referring, of course, to the proposal to remove excise duty on excisable airport shop goods purchased at inwards duty free shops provided such goods, in combination with customable goods, do not exceed one litre of alcoholic liquor or 250 grams of tobacco products. This proposal will put into place the idea that Australian travellers overseas will for the first time be able to purchase duty free goods in Australia on their return. This is a very important provision because it means that instead of people who want to take advantage of duty free concessions when they travel having to buy goods of other nations, they will be able to buy Australian goods on their return to Australia. That is one of the important first steps if we are to encourage people to buy Australian, rather than imported, goods. It is a wonder that this sort of approach has taken so long for us to develop. The only thing that I can say about it is that the measure has not been extended sufficiently because it applies only to alcohol and tobacco products. I do not see why we should not encourage the situation whereby people who, on returning from overseas, could purchase duty free at least the number of goods that are permissible under current circumstances, including a number of manufactured products.

This concession has important ramifications from the point of view of its potential impact on imports. It would especially have ramifications if it were extended in the way that I have suggested the Government ought to think about, that is, to extend it to other goods such as manufactured goods which are often brought into Australia with the duty free concession. Not only do I approve of this measure that has been put into place by this legislation but I also suggest that we try to expand it even further in the future. Hopefully, there will be a time when airport duty free areas will be mostly concerned with Australian made goods which are increasingly becoming more competitive on the world market.

Of course there are a number of other provisions in these Bills to which the Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Mr Barry Jones) referred when he introduced them. For example, we have provision for the abolition of the excise duty on wine produced with added sugar and revised definitions and restructured tariff items dealing with brandy, whisky, rum and liquers.

I want to focus on two other aspects of the Bill in the remaining minutes. The first concerns the third Bill, the Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill. In that Bill new powers are given to the Comptroller-General and it refers to the reasons why those powers have been given and why other powers have been retained in the hands of the Minister. The shadow Minister suggested that somehow there was some problems with the transfer of these responsibilities to the Comptroller-General. I remind him, however, that this transfer follows upon the original transfer of a substantial number of powers-basically administrative powers.

This further transfer is taking place only after an inquiry involving the Minister and the Australian Customs Service has been undertaken. It was only after that inquiry was undertaken and a determination was made to divide the administrative functions from the other functions-that is, the functions which are policy orientated-that it was found that only about 10 per cent of the powers and Customs rules are really needed for the Minister to be able to formulate and implement policy and other matters on the administrative side, including some of the important administrative decisions, should properly be left in the hands of the Comptroller-General. Of course, the Comptroller-General will still have to report to the Minister about any problems that arise in the general administration of the Customs Service; so it is not the case that the Minister is going to wash his hands of any administration requirements.

It is important that the Minister has retained certain powers which relate to the policy aspects of this whole area, in particular the powers for the extension of the variation of bounty assistance arrangements in relation to the protection of particular industries. Powers concerning customs tariffs alterations and the formulation of schemes for calling for and dealing with tenders for the right to import goods-in other words, a whole series of powers concerned with import licensing and with proposals dealing with customs tariffs alterations-have all been retained by the Minister.

In addition to these powers, the Minister will also retain a large number of important powers concerning dumping. The shadow Minister referred to the question of what would happen in regard to dumping. Why is it important that the Minister retain all these powers? It is important because we need constantly to re-evaluate and reconsider this whole area of import licensing, this whole area of bounty assistance and this whole area of anti-dumping provisions. It is particularly in this area of licensing and this area of customs tariff arrangements that we can provide a link between our industry policies on the one hand and our trade policies on the other. This essential link between industry and trade needs to be studied and developed if we are to overcome some of the fundamental problems that we have at present in relation to our trading situation. This link and these powers will be of pivotal importance. It is therefore extremely important that the Minister has retained those powers within his own hands.

I believe that we ought to inquire more actively into how those particular powers can be used in the current situation where the growth in the economy is excessively sucking imports into this country. I am not suggesting that those powers should be used in any heavy-handed fashion through some kind of across the board measure.
Debate interrupted.

a prima facie case of breach of privilege has been made out.
The first criterion has been satisfied.

In connection with the second requirement, I have noted that the right honourable gentleman has suggested that, in order to help me reach a conclusion, I should take steps to ensure that I am informed of the alternative views on the matter. However, my task in these matters is not to instigate inquiries, but rather to form a view, on the information made available to me, as to whether or not a prima facie case has been established, which would cause me to accord precedence to a motion.

The authorities are very clear in indicating that attempts by improper means to influence members in their parliamentary conduct are a breach of privilege. Attempted intimidation is an example, and acts tending indirectly to obstruct members in the discharge of their duty may also be treated as a breach of privilege. It is claimed that there was a proposal, the genesis of which I need not go into, that what may be described as the pursuit of a subject in Parliament should not be continued. If it is accepted that such a proposal was contemplated or discussed, it must be considered whether such actions constituted an attempt to influence members by improper means.

In addition, in matters such as this, I feel that I should restate my belief that all complaints of breach of privilege or contempt should be considered in light of the general reluctance of parliaments to invoke their privilege and contempt processes in cases other than those where it is considered imperative to do so in order to protect parliament against obstructions, or threats of obstruction, such as would involve substantial interference with its functioning.

On the information before me, I am not satisfied that the actions referred to constitute an attempt by improper means to influence members in their parliamentary conduct. In these circumstances, I do not find that a prima facie case of breach of privilege has been made out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in my mail I received the latest offering from the Priority One con game. I am pleased to see that the very well paid supposed head of that Priority One task force is in the chamber tonight to take note of some of my criticisms of that scheme. One only has to look at the material forwarded to parliamentarians and no doubt to a great many others in the community to realise just what an absolute and utter sham Priority One really is. The self-promotion of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the utter cynicism and the betrayal of the trust placed in the Government by so many young people-never to be repeated, I hasten to add-almost defy description.

SPEECH.PARA: On the front page of the Priority One broadsheet the Prime Minister's name is mentioned no fewer than eight times. There are only about eight paragraphs-it works out to be almost one Bob Hawke or one Prime Minister every sentence. Have a listen, Madam Speaker, to the very first paragraph alongside his smiling face. It states:

Most people have one, some have two. For three weeks in 1985 Bob Hawke had 32. And if you think 32 phones are excessive, you will be interested to know that they were all in constant use. But then, Bob Hawke was determined to lend an ear to young Australians and it seems that Prime Minister's ears are in great demand.

The very thick booklet, a very expensive publication no doubt widely distributed which attempts to interpret and detail the responses of that massively-promoted phone-in, is an exercise in trivia.
