It heads a whole number of subjects and purports to give summaries of the callers. So, on nuclear issues-this is the intellectual level of this booklet-it summarises by stating:
This is a very keenly felt area for many young Australians.
That is true. It continues:
Strong media coverage is likely to have contributed to the clarity with which individual issues are expressed.

Then it lists a whole number of callers, all, of course, who are anti-uranium, anti-American base, pro-nuclear free zone in their approach. It is absolute left-wing garbage. All the other topics under such headings as `Uranium', `US bases', `Africa', `Heritage', `Immigration' and `Wildlife' are meant only to be a reflection of government policy. Therefore, those callers who, in all honesty, tried to make a contribution by way of the phone-in have been duped and used. Of course, under the heading `The Law' it deals with the so-called gerrymander in Queensland. Is that not amazing? Several pages are handed over to Joh Bjelke-Petersen bashing. The whole thing is an absolute fraud. It is an expensive fraud. It is a cynical betrayal of the hopes and aspirations of a great many young Australians. Any Government member who adds his support to this is nothing but an utter disgrace to his electorate and to this Parliament. It is garbage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to bring to the attention of the House the ethics of journalists, in particular one Mr Mark Baker who writes for the Melbourne Age. I will bring several items before the House to back up my claim. Recently, in fact last week, I had the privilege of leading a delegation of seven members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence of this Parliament to Papua New Guinea where we had discussions with a number of Ministers, including Prime Minister Wingti, and a tour right around Papua New Guinea to the Ok Tedi gold and copper mine, refugee camps and a number of other places. It was a very interesting and informative tour, but it was in relation to the refugee camps that Mr Baker decided that he had better justify his employer's expense of sending him to Papua New Guinea to be with the delegation, because his reports do not reflect the truth of what happened there.

SPEECH.PARA: The Age article of 22 April headlined `Jakarta threat to reject aid', from a reporter of Australian Associated Press, states:

In another development, Mark Baker reports from Wewak on Papua New Guinea's northern coast that a row has broken out amongst an Australian Federal parliamentary delegation over a Labor member's charge that Indonesia is a `bully' attempting to wipe out Melanesian culture.

I do not wish to debate that. That point was made by the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent). He has a right to make those statements and I do not wish to debate them here. In fact, the Committee has'nt even debated them. I say that to put the article into context. The article continues:

Mr Kent was censured tonight for his criticism by a special meeting of the delegation. The leader of the delegation, Mr David Charles, the Labor member for Isaacs in Victoria, refused to comment on Mr Kent's outbursts.

The first untruth is that no special meeting was called specifically to discuss any comments in that regard. Half-way through the tour I called a meeting which had been organised before we left Port Moresby with the secretary of the Committee, Mr Phil Bergin, to revise what had occurred in the first few days and in particular what we had seen at the refugee camps and at other sites such as Ok Tedi. It was raised at that meeting whether we should make individual statements or speak as a Committee. There was discussion around that point, but the beat-up by Mr Baker is totally false.

Another article was run on 24 April. On the front page it is stated: `MPs call for tough stand'. That is the stand by three members of the Committee in relation to the discussions about Indonesia-nothing to do with the Committee's trip or what we saw. That is their right, and every member in the House has a view on Indonesia, I suppose. In relation to that I quote from the Melbourne Age as follows:

Their stand, and their backing of Mr Kent's description of Indonesia as a `bully' attempting to wipe out Melanesian culture, has widened the split in the seven-member delegation which has just completed visits to refugee camps on the PNG-Indonesian border.

Mr Baker has again tried to look at the issue of Indonesia, on the one hand, and the Committee, on the other, to bring them all together and relate them. They have absolutely no relation whatsoever. Once again, it is a scandalous beat-up and an attempt to make a story out of something that just was not there.

Further to that, to show the integrity of this particular journalist, I refer to last Saturday's edition of the Melbourne Age. In completely different circumstances, the front page headline states: `Take in Irians, pleads PNG'. The article states:

The Papua New Guinea Prime Minister, Mr Wingti, has attacked Australian policy on Irian Jayan refugees and called on the Federal Government to resettle some of the hundreds of guerilla supporters living in PNG border camps.
The very next day a Press release came from the Papua New Guinea Prime Minister, Paias Wingti, in which it is stated:

The Papua New Guinea Government had not criticised Australia over resettlement of Irian Jaya refugees held in camps in PNG, the Prime Minister Mr Paias Wingti said today. Mr Wingti said his Government had not even formally asked Australia to take any refugees, let alone criticised Australia for something it had not expressed a view on.
Further in the rather lengthy Press release, it is stated:
The Prime Minister said weekend media reports quoting him as saying Australia had offered reasons for not taking refugees had been quoted entirely out of context.

Madam Speaker, I put to you that the various articles, the beat-ups of what occurred in what was a very good delegation which had a very interesting and informative trip, all really show that some journalists are scurrilous and have no ethics. It is little wonder that some people call into question the ethics of Australian journalists in Asia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to address some comments to the House about the Armenian community in Australia. April 24 each year marks the date on which the genocide of Armenian people in Turkey in 1915 and beyond is commemorated. This year is the seventy-first anniversary of the first and one of the worst acts of genocide perpetrated on mankind this century. From available evidence, more than 1 1/2 million Armenians were slaughtered for no better reason than being an ethnic community, unwanted in their own homeland. Armenian culture has developed and, despite frequent challenges and enormous difficulties, has endured for well over 2,000 years. By contrast, our Australian culture is still in its infancy-it is not yet 200 years old. Nevertheless, we are most fortunate to have an opportunity to enrich and strengthen the Australian nation by embracing the heritage and traditions of so many people from many lands who now call Australia home.

SPEECH.PARA: The Armenian people have suffered much, been confronted by, and overcome many hardships through the centuries to retain their culture and to preserve their heritage and traditions-those things which are distinctively and especially Armenian. Their desire for independence and freedom for themselves and their beloved nation; the courage, enterprise and skills of the Armenian people; their determination and resolve to remember the great and colourful, although often tragic, history of the Armenian nation; the influence of a religion which is based on one of the oldest branches of the Christian faith-all these are qualities that will ensure that Armenians everywhere continue their development as an independent, freedom-loving people. They are also the qualities which have played a significant role in ensuring the successful resettlement of Armenians in Australia and which will continue to ensure that we may all work together in harmony, each with respect and understanding for the other, so that our plans and hopes for a better, more secure and happier future will be realised.

As a community, distinct but not separate, Armenians will, I am sure, continue to contribute to the development of a cohesive multicultural society in Australia. I have no doubt that the Armenian community will continue to make many significant contributions to the development of their adopted home, and that as a result Australian institutions, culture and traditions will be enriched and extended across a wider, brighter, more interesting tapestry. I encourage all Armenians in Australia to make as full a contribution to our community as they can. We will all share and appreciate the benefits now and in the future. Let us all work together at living together, so that in time Mount Kosciusko may replace Mount Ararat in Armenian hearts and dreams.

Perhaps in their hearts and minds they have all died a little-or a lot-for beloved Armenia. Perhaps they still cry for her and for her brave and bloodied past and people. But as we remember the glories and the sacrifices of the past, we must be careful not to let them overwhelm our plans and hopes for, and our faith in, the future. It is a future where the dying and crying are but sacred and revered memories recalled and commemorated, as they must and should be, in the freedom, security and peace of a world which has no option but to realise that there is no alternative to the fact that we are a universal and international family, a brotherhood and sisterhood of men and women who must learn to live, with goodwill and understanding, together.

As we recall tonight the tragedy of the Armenian genocide, let us not do so in any spirit of hopelessness or revenge, but with the determination and commitment that will ensure that such a ghastly atrocity is not-ever again-perpetrated by one nation upon another, for whatever the cause. We have had enough of terrorism in all its dreadful forms. Let us at least learn from the horrific lessons of history, so that in future our children and our children's children inherit a world where the wounds of the past have been allowed to heal, but their scars remain as a necessary and salutary reminder of the depths to which humanity can sink if we do not commit ourselves to achieving justice, freedom and dignity for all people everywhere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take a couple of minutes of the time of the House to raise an issue which has received some attention-adverse attention-in the media in the last few weeks arising out of a campaign by the people of the western suburbs of Sydney to try to improve their accessibility to tertiary institutions, especially a university. There has been some publicity suggesting that the standards of students in the western suburbs are too low to warrant the existence of a tertiary institution. When I saw those remarks-and I am not saying that statistically they may not be accurate in regard to totals-I remembered that on 1 March this year the Sydney Morning Herald published a list of top students. The list was introduced in the following way:

SPEECH.PARA: A list of the top one per cent of students in the 1985 Higher School Certificate has been issued by the Board of Senior School Studies.

That list as published consisted of names without addresses, plus the schools where the students had sat for their Higher School Certificate. I went through the list in terms of the schools in my electorate, picked out the names, and checked them against addresses on the electoral roll. I found six students in that list of 250 who lived in my electorate and attended schools there.

In addition to those six there could obviously be others who attend private schools outside the electorate or so-called selective high schools, such as James Ruse, which is not very far from my electorate, which had the best results of all schools in the last Higher School Certificate examinations. The important point is that there were at least six students in this category. There are 53 electorates in New South Wales, there were 250 students in the top one per cent, and therefore the average would be just under five per electorate. We in fact had six or six-plus in that category. The point I am trying to emphasise is that obviously there are some outstanding students in the area. I congratulate those students and that is the reason why I sought to find their names.

One point I would like to make is that there has been a campaign against external examinations, run to some extent by the Teachers Federation or some part of that Federation in New South Wales. Of those six students, two attended Holroyd High School, one Greystanes High School, one Fairfield High School, and two Patrician Brothers, Fairfield. If somebody without external examinations tried to get a job with an employer and said that he went to Fairfield High School, Holroyd High School, Greystanes High School or Patrician Brothers, Fairfield, I think the attitude to the employer in many cases would be that the standards there are much lower than the standards represented by the schools in the area, for example, of the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton).

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is that?

—Because people have ridiculous ideas that if one goes to a high school at St Ives, somehow the standards are higher than they are at Holroyd High School. The only chance open to students from areas with lower socio-economic reputations is for them to sit in competitive examinations and to show quite clearly that they are able to compete with students from other areas and to come out on top. I congratulate the six students concerned and the teachers at the schools they attended, but the specific point I make is that there are some excellent students in the area. They deserve access, and to some extent they already have access, to institutes of higher learning in Sydney. Everything should be done to make it possible for people to advance via competitive examinations in our society.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In introducing the Community Employment Amendment Bill some time ago, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) stated that the Hawke Government had allocated $1 billion to the community employment program over three Budgets. At that time 16,000 projects had been funded and 87,000 short term employment opportunities had been created for the long term unemployed, who represented 62 per cent of all CEP placements. One recognises that $1 billion is a lot of money. One must also recognise that the average duration of unemployment suffered by individuals is lengthening. It was around 34 weeks out of work in 1981, and latest figures for 1985 indicate that 52 weeks of unemployment was the mean. The community employment program notwithstanding, young people are unemployed longer before they find a job today.

SPEECH.PARA: Jobstart, a scheme arranged to provide a subsidy to potential employees who are long term unemployed, probably has a lot more going for it than the Commonwealth employment program. The takeup rate by employers would indicate that wage costs are a barrier to taking on new staff, and this of course was corroborated by Priority One, the Budget strategy for young people. I believe that was an admission by the Labor Government that its policies and attitudes towards youth unemployment have been out of touch with reality. Of course, it remains for the Government to pursue the logic of the wage subsidy component of both programs and support the deregulation of the labour market in certain circumstances, thus widening the employment and training opportunities for all.

However, because that is not likely, I would like to comment on a disincentive factor in the jobstart scheme. Any unemployed person who is keen and willing to undertake part time work can, by his very actions, be penalised by being ruled ineligible to obtain a full time job if over the nine month period he has worked three months at 15 hours per week. Of course, the reward for some in this scheme, that is, a job, is sitting on their backsides and not undertaking any form of casual or part time work and, in fact, not even looking for any. I wonder why it is that in this country we are rewarding some people who will not look for work and in many cases penalising the fellow who is prepared to have a go at anything. This discriminatory aspect of jobstart has been brought to my attention a number of times, most recently by Eddie Kelly, a very disappointed father in Bundaberg who was trying to find part time work for his family and was prepared to do any sort of casual work.

I remember reading in the Australian newspaper last year of the difficulty crop growers were experiencing in obtaining labour to harvest their crops-asparagus and citrus fruits readily come to mind. Mr Ron Parr from Mundubbera, a citrus growing area, rang me in my office here and said that he could not get enough pickers for his orange crops. This is in a region which has over twice the average unemployment rate. The only ones willing to work were some Swedes who, unfortunately for Mr Parr, had no work visas. The end result in such circumstances is a loss to the grower in unharvested or late harvested crops and no reduction in the transfer of public moneys from the producing sectors to the unemployed.

People continually ask me, especially when they see an Australian newspaper with a front page photo of a fellow boasting that he has not looked for work for six years, why the unemployed should be paid for doing nothing. I believe they have a point. If we look at three years of CEP, it is $1 billion. The estimate for unemployment benefit payments for 1985-86 is almost $3 billion. That is a lot of money. Participants in CEP schemes work for local authorities and governments as well as community groups. It appears they are doing the work well and the schemes are considered beneficial to the community.

Taking the figures supplied in the Budget Estimates, I must ask: Why cannot those 540,000 unemployed who will average $100 a week in benefit payments for 1985-86 put in a couple of days work with those or similar organisations which are now employing CEP participants? There appears to be an organisation structure which can utilise the unemployed for productive work, so with some modification why not give the opportunity to utilise the pool of labour in excess of half a million and benefit the country? The 16-year-old may need to do a day's work and the married man three days work per week-all productive and paid for by unemployment benefit money, and the taxpayers will get something for their taxes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence my comments tonight by supporting the remarks that were made by the honourable member for Casey (Mr Halverson) in relation to the Armenians. I think those comments were very timely and appropriate. I am very pleased to hear a member of the Opposition making those sorts of comments. I think the way the honourable member expressed the cause was, as I said, timely and I think also in a very sensitive fashion.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I will deal with the situation which is being imposed on the Australian people by the major banks. Some time earlier I raised in this House and in other places the way that the Commonwealth Bank in particular was imposing loan service fees on home mortgages, and those fees were being applied on a sliding scale which in effect made them simply de facto increases in mortgage interest rates. As a result of that publicity from me and many others, the banks were forced into withdrawing-particularly the Commonwealth Bank and some others-those loan service fee amounts that they were proposing to impose. The result was a very good one for ordinary Australians struggling to pay their mortgage bills.

However, recently I have had brought to my attention the fact that the National Australia Bank is now advertising that it is prepared to pay to people who invest in that bank 16.6 per cent interest per annum on special accounts. However, when one looks more closely at these advertisements one finds underneath the 16.6 per cent per annum, in tiny print, the word `effective'. I am told that, when one checks to see just what interest the bank is paying in terms of the normally expressed interest rates, the actual amount is only 15.8 per cent. I think that this sort of misleading advertising by a leading bank is very worrying indeed. If this were a less supposedly reputable organisation, I have no doubt at all that people would be talking about fly by night finance companies, and so on. In fact, because it is a large national organisation, it seems to be able to get away with it.

I think it is quite disgraceful that a supposedly reputably organisation should advertise in this way. I do not believe that the National Australia Bank needs to do this. I certainly think it is particularly concerning that this advertisement seems to be pitched at older people-pensioners and retired people-who have money to invest. The normal rate that seems to be available is about 16 per cent, and by advertising that it is offering money at 16.6 per cent I have no doubt that it is endeavouring to steal a march on its more honest competitors in this particular manner. I think that this is just another example of the way the banks seems to operate in this country-in a quite cavalier fashion, almost oblivious of the normal standards required in dealing as business corporations in our society. I think it is pretty unsatisfactory and I think it is about time some action was taken to ensure that this sort of deceptive advertising does not continue. No doubt the argument will be put up that everyone knows what `effective interest rates' means if one can read the fine print and that if one knows something about the law and the law of lending one may be able to work through it. However, for ordinary lay people who would not be aware of such things, I think it is a pretty shabby performance. I think we ought to be able to expect better of a leading financial institution such as the National Australia Bank and I hope that it will withdraw this advertisement at an early time and start advertising the interest rates that it applies in simple interest rate terms which everyone understands and not `effective', `compound' or any other types of interest rates that are used only to mislead the public at large.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 February this year I placed on the Notice Paper question No. 3248 to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The question I asked is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Did the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) prepare a valuation of the plant and equipment at the Belconnen Mall, ACT; if so, will he table the valuation in the House.
(2) Did the ATO valuation of the Belconnen Mall contain any component for redevelopment of the site.
(3) Is the apportionment, in the agreement for sale, of $8,921,710, which is listed as goods, for plant and equipment.
(4) If the ATO did not prepare a valuation of plant and equipment what steps did he take to verify the figure of $8,921,710.

(5) Is the Commonwealth now prevented from disputing the correctness of the figure of $8,921,710; if so, how does he reconcile this with his answer to my question without notice (Hansard, 14 February 1986, pages 585-6) concerning the sale of Belconnen Mall.
(6) Did he read in full the agreement for sale prior to its execution.

(7) Is it a fact that if the figure of $8,921,710 for plant and equipment is maintained and upheld (a) there will be a tax windfall to the purchasers in excess of $2.4 million, (b) the purchasers will be entitled to claim nearly $5 million for further depreciation of plant and equipment which had already been depreciated by the Canberra Commercial Development Authority and (c) there will be an additional tax burden of $2.4 million imposed upon the Canberra Commercial Development Authority.
(8) Is he able to say whether the Canberra Commercial Development Authority is satisfied with the situation.

(9) Did he discuss the proposed sale with the Minister for Territories prior to the close of tenders; if so, (a) on what dates, (b) at what places and (c) what were the material particulars of the discussion.
(10) Did he consider the arrangement of Commonwealth-funded bridging finance to facilitate the sale of the Belconnen Mall
(11) Was the option of writing-up plant and equipment offered to any of the other tenderers prior to the close of tenders.

Madam Speaker, as you know, I am a very patient man. But that series of questions has remained on the Notice Paper unanswered for 70 days. That is nearly 20 per cent of the year. It is a scandal and a disgrace that those questions remain unanswered. The Prime Minister has just returned from a trip. He is probably tired and jetlagged. I called his office and found that he has returned to the Lodge. But I must say that my patience is fast becoming exhausted. This is a scandalous situation in that the Belconnen shopping centre, which is worth well over $100m, has been flogged off to a preferred purchaser, a preferred tenderer, for a mere $89m. I have placed a series of 11 questions on the Notice Paper. They remain unanswered. The matter has now been taken up by the national Press. There was an article in the National Times 10 days ago, which I am sure has now been brought to the Prime Minister's attention, involving the relationship between his Government and Westfield Property Trust in relation to this sale of the century windfall price of the Belconnen Mall, together with other property dealings in Sydney which are of grave concern. I now inform the House that I am aware that there was an Australian Taxation Office valuation of the plant and equipment. I further inform the House that it did not-

TALK.START.PARA: —How much was it?

—It was well below the figure that could have been obtained, namely, $102m on a tender put in by a Western Australian corporation. It did not contain a component in relation to redevelopment of the site. Moreover there is the question of revenue. I note the presence in the Parliament tonight of the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). I will invite him to pursue this matter. There has been a writing-up of plant and equipment which, had it been done by private enterprise, would have led to a prosecution for criminal conspiracy. There has been a shifting of a tax burden in favour of a preferred tenderer to the disadvantage of a statutory authority, a matter which I regard as very suspicious. The Prime Minister is now on notice that he has seven days to answer these questions. If he does not, he will have to face the consequences.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak totally unprepared, and I seek the indulgence of the House. I am extremely concerned at the announcement that there has been a major nuclear disaster in the Soviet Union. As one who has condemned the nuclear industry in the United States of America and elsewhere, I feel equally passionate about any accident that is perpetrated on the people of this world, whether they be people from the Soviet Union, the United States or anywhere else. I honestly believe that we have reason to be concerned, and I hope passionately that those honourable members opposite who have smirks on their faces tonight will have the same smirks on their faces in 12 months' time. If they are smiling then, I will enjoy that too.

SPEECH.PARA: I have no prepared speech, but I wish to place on record in the House tonight my deep and passionate concern about where we are going. In trying to put together some words to say that would be appropriate, I grabbed some words from a speech I made regarding Harrisburg and the Three Mile Island disaster, where what occurred to a nuclear reactor was called an incredible event-often referred to as the China syndrome. I understand that the Soviet Union may well be facing such an event and that the Soviet Government has called on other government for assistance in trying to put out a fire that has got out of control as a result of an accident at the Chernobyl nuclear reactor.

I want to say, totally off the cuff, that sometimes when I have had the opportunity to speak in my own Caucus I have asked colleagues of the Left, the Centre and Right to show respect for one another's views. I know that many people have a great concern about where we are going down the nuclear path. I said in my Caucus-I do not think my colleagues will be upset if I repeat it-that I would like to have in our Caucus room, emblazoned above our Chairman, the slogan `Respect one another', so that we can see it and listen to each other's arguments and respect them. I believe in that. I accept decisions when I do not have the numbers on certain issues, but let us respect each other.

With regard to those people who have been gung ho about the nuclear path, I find it hard to respect their views on that subject, because there is so much evidence that they are going the wrong way. I ask them to stop and think and look at the evidence. I say to them: `Please, just do that'. Tonight let us all forget the differences, even the party differences, and look at what has happened in the Soviet Union today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—I wish to reject a description made of this Parliament today in the Sydney Morning Herald that it is merely a sausage machine. I think that the rich tapestry provided in the adjournment debate which is coming to a close tonight and in other adjournment debates is proof enough that this Parliament is more than a sausage machine. The recent Builders Labourers Federation deregistration Bill was an example of fast-track legislation being amended by the Senate in a way that just did not merely rubber stamp the original proposals of the Government. The veterans' entitlements package-a massive package which took more than 11 months to be digested by this Parliament-is yet another example of Parliament doing its duty on that occasion by the veterans, and not rubber stamping the original Government proposals. Indeed, I reject outright that this Parliament is in any shape or form a sausage machine. I have to say that the Parliament I left-the State Parliament in Sydney-could be regarded as a sausage machine because of the way in which it conducts its proceedings, with Ministers merely tabling second reading speeches on recent occasions. That is the culmination of arrogance.
—Order! It being 11 p.m., the debate is interrupted. The House stands adjourned until 10 a.m. tomorrow.
